div.p: AS IT IS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE-ROYAL, COVENT-GARDEN.
div.q: You fashionable People are very vulgar! GINGHAM.

item.label: Servants to the Hon. Mr. Savage
Servants to the Hon. Mr. Savage

lg.l: HOW narrow is the sphere a modern Bays
Is doom'd to range, while he contrives his Plays;
Still urg'd by folly, Beings to explore,
Whom he and you so often saw before:
Precluded characters by their advance,
Whose minds could pierce thro' Nature with a glance,
And still of right possess the moral Stage
With lessons studied in a distant age;
In this, our glass, you yet reflected find
The levities which lessen human kind:
The lighter follies which the Town engage,
All that prevail in fashion makes—the Rage;
Yes, all! though various be the motly forms,
That sway by weak'ning, or compel in storms:
That up to Fop evaporate the Lord;
Or down to Jockey sink the Maid ador'd;
Confound distinctions, firm and frail perplex,
And make it difficult—to guess even sex.
But is the Rage to levity confin'd?
Does no just passion sway the general mind?
Lo! the rough Veteran, whom his Country's claim,
Rouses to vindicate her injured name!
The Rage is Conquest which his bosom fires,
The foe yields! then—no! then his rage expires.
When in some dreadful contest on the wave
The gallant seaman finds a wat'ry grave,
E'er the last pulse of ebbing life be o'er,
When the eye turns towards his native shore,
This thought may ev'n the parting pang assuage
That, there—Humanity is still the Rage.
Our Author's Muse follows with fashion's gale,
Down a smooth river an amusive sail;
She dares no sea where boisterous passions sway,
Or merely dips her wing, and hastes away.
O may her airy toil your love engage,
And her new flight to please you be—The Rage.
WELL, Gentlefolks, again your most obedient;
That I'm the Epilogue is held expedient:
Our Bard, who for a youth well knows the Stage,
Thought as to speaking, Women were "The Rage,"
And said—"Good Mrs. Mattocks, pray, advance;
Females must now step forward as in France."
My answer was—my dear, kind Sir, have pity,
"Pray spare the Ladies—Men secure our city.
"For arm'd by Parliament, to calm each fear,
"Huge corps of Common-Councilmen appear,
"Wards, Liveries, Deputies, en Militaire,
"Led by Lieutenant-Colonel—my Lord Mayor!
"Each man, (a sight at which his Lady swoons,)
"Belt, sabre, helmet, spurs, and pantaloons!
"Dear Chuck"—says Spouse—"pray sit at home, do yielde,
"Consider, Love, your age; you grow unwieldy;
"Good twenty stone, Dear, cannot play about,
"Besides those cold Jack Boots hurt Lovey's Gout."
"Gout! vulgar nonsense Voman—Gout! Gad's curse,
"Heavy! why I'm a private of Light Horse—
"Dress! wheel! charge!—Could I on Horseback get
"I or my horse would do some mischief yet.'
Thus, meaning no offence, in language faint,
The City Rage for soldiering we paint.
But sure no sons of Briton, wish represt
That zeal which leads one man to serve the rest;
Which strives due right and order to maintain,
Against a Chaos that would come again.
Long may such Rage inspire the English mind!
In neighbouring Climes a different "Rage" we find;
Poor Jean François who shouts for Liberté
Finds Slavery still the Order of the Day!
"Ma foi! he cries—no people blest as we
They force me out to fight to make me free,
Den! vif! alert!—begar we must not tarry,
My Vife, for common good, oblige to marry:
She labour for the State, tant mieux pour elle,
She forget me—I her—c'est Bagatelle!
Allons au Guerre! L'eau de vie banish sorrow,
Victoire to-day—La Guillotine to-morrow!"
English Tom Blunt, a dealer in small wares,
Who knows a bit what's passing above stairs.
Cries—"Why in that there change of wives so fast
"I think a good one mayhap may come at last,
"But in that gulleting machine, d'ye see,
"I've no idea how it makes one free:
"For my part now, whatever may be said,
"I'm for a little meat, and safe warm bed,
"I does not relish freedom—when one's dead;
"So once for all my means and resolution
"Go, to stand by the good old Constitution."
Such and so different reign with sovereign power,
The various "Rages" of the present hour.
I wish, in truth I wish in very spight,
Your Rage may be, to see us many a night.

div.head: SCENE I.—DARNLEY'S Garden, and view of his small Villa.
div.stage: Enter DARNLEY and Sir GEORGE GAUNTLET.

sp.speaker: SIR GEORGE.
sp.p: AND so, Darnley, you prefer this solitary life, to all the joys of London—to be sure you've a nice snug Villa, and a charming wife here—but its dull—the scene tires—it wants variety, Harry.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p:
No, Sir George.—Since I retir'd to this peaceful spot, I have not had a wish be
yond it: I've been so happy in that humble cottage, that when I'm doom'd to leave it, the world will be a waste, and life not have a charm!

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p:
How you are alter'd, Darnley? When we were brother officers you were the greatest rake in the regiment; but from the
time we were quarter'd at Worcester, where you first beheld Miss Dormer—

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: I saw the folly of my former life; I own'd the power of her superior charms, and leaving a busy and tumultuous world, retir'd with her to this sequester'd scene—'tis now three years since I married.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: And from that time to this, have you liv'd in this out-of-the-way place?

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p:
Yes: and till you yesterday honour'd me with a visit, I have not seen a friend within my doors—but isn't it a happy life, Sir George? Our affections have room to shoot—care and distrust are banish'd from our cottage, and with such a woman as Mrs. Darnley to con
verse with, what is the world to me? I can defy and scorn its malice.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p:
She's an angelic creature indeed, Darnley: and at Worcester, I had myself near
ly fallen a victim to her charms; but about your future life—do you mean to live for ever in these woods and meadows?

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: No—would to heaven I could!—I fear I must forego my present calm, and mix in active life again: When I married, I sold my commission, you remember, to purchase this small farm—Mrs. Darnley's portion was but a trifle, and an encreasing family has so enlarg'd my expences, that unless I return to the army—

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Ah—you want to be raking again?

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p:
No—I want to secure an indepen
dence for my family—I want to see my chil
dren affluent, and to attain this, I have once more applied to my uncle Sir Paul Perpetual,
who was so offended at my selling out, that he has ever since abandon'd me.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: What—does the old beau still persevere in his resentment?

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p:
His anger has encreas'd; for he writes me word; he intends marrying Lady Sa
rah Savage, on purpose to have heirs more worthy his estate:—Oh! my friend:—'tis hard, that fortune should bestow such treasures, and then compel me to desert them?

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p:
So it is: but now I think on't, this Lady Sarah Savage and her brother are my intimate friends; and as you are their neighbours, I'll introduce you and Mrs. Darn
ley to their notice—When are they expected from town?

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: To day.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Then we'll pay them a visit: Lady Sarah Savage shall interfere with your uncle, and if that fails, her brother can easily ensure your promotion in the army—but see; here's Mrs. Darnley?

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: Look at her, Sir George—do you, can you blame me?—who would not act as I have done?

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: I would by heav'ns!—I'd live with her in a hermitage!—die with her on a pilgrimage!—I'd—sdeath: if I don't mind, I shall discover all.

sp.speaker: Darnley advancing to her.
sp.p: Maria!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p:
Oh Harry!—I have been look
ing for you every where—I declare you're grown quite a truant—Before your friend came, you
us'd to walk with me over the farm: or ride with me to see our children; or sit and read to me under our favourite Beach Tree—but now—Sir George!—I beg your pardon—I didn't see you before.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p:
My friend is all kindness, Maria; he has promis'd to introduce me to the honour
able Mr. Savage:

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: What:—take you to Savage house!

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: Ay—why not:—you shall go with me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: No—let me stay here—I am not weary of my present life.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: Nor I—but 'tis a great connexion: and though not absolutely distress'd, I would improve my fortune—I would see you and my children have every comfort.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: We have, while you are with us—consider we have never liv'd a day apart, and if they lure you into fashionable scenes, you'll be corrupted, Harry—you'll despise the humble roof you once rever'd, and I perhaps shall be forgotten and neglected.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p:
Never!—I cannot bear the suppo
sition; and while we have hearts to endure, and hands to labour, there is sufficient for our cottage!—I will not go—My friend, who sees my motive, I'm sure, will not condemn me.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p:
No—always obey the Ladies; but Darnley, I see our horses—you recollect we were to ride to see your children: so, Ma
dam, I have the superlative honour—

div.stage: Enter CLARA SEDLEY—a basket of flowers is hanging on her arm, and she is eating an apple.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: What, Clara!—been picking flowers my angel!—well!—I thought they had all died—all died from envy egad! ha! ha!—excuse me—I never laugh but at my own wit.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p:
Do you? then you laugh very sel
dom, I believe.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: No—very often: for I take the joke though nobody else does, ha! ha!—come Darnley—adieu Ladies—I'll not run away with him!—

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: What a coxcomb it is!—and if he wasn't a duellist into the bargain, I'd tell Mr. Darnley all my suspicions—that I would—but he's so fond of fighting, that I heard him say, he once sent a man a challenge for wafering a letter instead of sealing it.—I wish he was gone.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Indeed so do I, cousin—Mr. Darnley is so chang'd since he arriv'd—his ideas so enlarg'd—he talks of visiting at Savage House, of improving his fortune.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p:
Fortune!—ay: and this morning he gave me his note for two hundred pounds, beg
ging me to get one of my guardians to lend money upon it—his excuse was that his expen
ces exceeded his income, and by his uncle's marriage with Lady Sarah Savage, all his ex
pectations were ruined—Now, my life on't, this is all Sir George's doings—He has stole into our cottage like the Arch-fiend into paradise, and I won't eat another apple while he stays!
sp.stage: (Throws away the apple she is eating.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Is Darnley then distressed?—Oh Clara!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Don't be unhappy—I shall apply to both my guardians; Sir Paul and Mr. Flush, they are now at Bath, and one way or other the Villa shall flourish still—Lord! I shall have plenty of money when I come of age, and I'll throw it all into the scale, and come and plant, sow, and reap with you and your husband.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: What give up the gaieties of London, cousin?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p:
London! ay: I hate it—I once pass'd a month there, but they hurried me so from sight to sight, that in the bustle all places ap
pear'd alike—I saw no difference—And, if you'll believe me, one morning after seeing West
minster Hall in term time, they took me in
side Bedlam; and so confus'd was I, that I didn't know the lawyers and their clients, from the keepers and their patients.
"Trompite, trompite tra!"

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Who can this be?
"Tra—tra—tra!"

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Bless us!—What animal's this?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: He has mistaken his way, I suppose—Sir— (Signor don't regard her.) I beg pardon, Sir—but perhaps you don't know that this garden—

sp.speaker: Signor.
sp.p: "Beviamo tutta trè!"—ah, ha!— les Demoiselles!—Ladies, à votre service.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Signor.
sp.p:
I and the Honourable Mister Savage arrive last night—ce Matin I take a my little valk—see your small Chateau, and am so en
chanté w illegible h the spectàcle that—me voici!—I honour you with my first visit—eh bien!—vat is your names?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Our names!—rather we should ask yours.

sp.speaker: Signor.
sp.p: Mine!—Diable!—do you not know me?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: No—how should we?

sp.speaker: Signor.
sp.p: Vat! not know I am Signor Cygnet— de first Violin in Europe! de best composer in de whole world!—de husband of Signora Cygnet —de great singer at de opera—de professional—de Abbey—de—Marbleu!—and am I not myself?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: No—I don't think you are yourself.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: And so, Sir, you are on a visit at Mr. Savage's?

sp.speaker: Signor.
sp.p:
Oui—in my vay to Bath I con
descend to pass a few days there—Lady Sarah Savage, she love music, or pretend to love— vich is de same ting you know—they entertain me comme çâ—give me good dinners, and take ticketts for mine and my vife's concert—mais there be two tings I don't like.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: And what are they, Sir?

sp.speaker: Signor.
sp.p: Vy Mister Savage, he give me cold suppers and sleep in the best bed himself—Now, begar!—I vill have hot suppers and de best bed, or else I take a my fiddle and promenez—"Malbrouk s'en va, &c." (Singing.)—De grand Duke—O! de grand Duke—he never use me thus—never—jamais!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: The Grand Duke!

sp.speaker: Signor.
sp.p: Oui—ven I was at Florence how you tink he treat me? accoutez—he quarrel with all his Ministers—all but one!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: And who was that one?

sp.speaker: Signor.
sp.p: Me!—me he shake by the hand and go to my vife's benefit toût le même—de same as ever!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Upon my word, music seems so important a science, that I think you had better let your little boy have some lessons—it is necessary for his education—isn't it, Signor?

sp.speaker: Signor.
sp.p:
Necessaire!—ma foi: 'tis de only education now-a-days—never mind vat you call Latin and Greek—put de fiddle in his lit
tle hand and let him scrape away! den he vill be great man—like me: and call for hot sup
per and best bed verever he go!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: What! shall I give up making a parson of him, Clary?

sp.speaker: Signor.
sp.p: Parson!—pif!—vat is de parson to de musician?—he ride his old white horse—preach away at four or five churches, and vat he get?—forty pounds a year—Eh bien! I and my vife ride in vis-a-vis—sing only ven we like, and make five thousand a year—ah ha! voila la difference!—Parson!—begar! de blind fidler get more money!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: More shame for the country then, where foreign arrogance is so rewarded, and gentlemanly merit so insulted—come Clara—

sp.speaker: Sir George
sp.p: Don't be alarmed, Mrs. Darnley; but I and your husband have just been present at an accident, that—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: An accident, sir!

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p:
Yes: Lady Sarah Savage, who is one of those ladies call'd female phaetoneers, was driving four in hand across the heath; the horses took fright, and ran away with her, when Darnley, with more gallantry than pru
dence, rode a-head of the unruly animals, and stopt them on the edge of a precipice.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Heaven be prais'd!—and where is the lady, sir?

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: My friend is conducting her to the villa, where he begs you'll instantly join them.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: By all means—come—

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Signor, won't you assist your friend?

sp.speaker: Signor.
sp.p: Non—I am musician, not physician, and my head is so full of de tune.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: So full of de vapour, he means—like the inside of his own violin—come cousin—now isn't it a pity, that while we have butterflies and bullfinches in the garden, we should be tormented with coxcombs and fiddlers—insects, adieu

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Signor, I rejoice to see you; you have often assisted me in my amours, and I now want your aid more than ever.

sp.speaker: Signor.
sp.p: Eh bien!—my vife has a concert at Bath next week.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p:
Has she! then I'll give a dinner to some Somersetshire bumpkins, and force off
a score or two of tickets—You saw the lady I first spoke to—she has won my heart, and I have won her husband's.

sp.speaker: Signor.
sp.p: Dat is good—den if you make de discord between them—

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p:
Ay, Sgnior: if I excite jealousy! and this accident has sprung the mine—Lady Sarah Savage is already half in love with Darn
ley—She has invited him to Savage house, and if he takes Mrs. Darnley along with him—

sp.speaker: Signor.
sp.p: Dey will be both out of tune for ever—ah ha! I go to Mr. Savage, toutesuite.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Do—and increase Lady Sarah's love for Darnley—assist in all my schemes; triumph I must, and will; for I offer'd Mrs. Darnley my hand long before this husband won her heart.

sp.speaker: Signor.
sp.p:
I will be first fiddle rest assurè—tenez; I vill compose two duettos—one between Lady Sarah Savage and de husband—de other be
tween you and de vife—allòns. You no con
ceive the power of music, Sir George.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: I do, Signor—for as Shakespeare says: There's nought so stockish, hard and full of rage, but music for a time does change its nature.

sp.speaker: Signor.
sp.p: Shakespeare! vat is dat Shakespeare? He never compose a single tune, and dough at present he make a little noise, begar, you'll soon find de fiddle and de bravura vill lay him on de shelf—now-a-days, sound always get de better of sense, mon ami—Ah ha! venez! you no forget my vife's benefit.

div.head: SCENE II.—A Room inside Mr. DARNLEY'S Villa, Prints, Books, Fowling Pieces, Fishing Tackle, &c.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p:
Well Clara: if Lady Sarah Savage be a picture of town-bred women of fashion, let me remain a plain simple rustic all my life—Did you ever see any thing so confi
dent—so masculine—her brother too! "What you call impudence," says he, "we call ease."

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Ay: they're a precious pair; and yet in London they are both the Rage!—quite at the top of the beau monde—But, cousin, they've order'd their carriages, and insist on our going to Savage house—Mercy on us! what's to become of two lambs amongst such a parcel of wolves?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p:
This is Sir George's scheme: to delude Mr. Darnley from this tranquil spot into fashionable life, is the first step towards af
fecting his base designs—He told Mr. Savage about your fortune too—

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: I know it: and the vulgar man made downright love to me directly;—'faith-Coz. I believe Sir George wants to get me married, and you unmarried.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah Savage without.)
sp.p: Bring round the Phaeton, and d'ye hear—don't tighten the curbs—I'll whip and gallop them every inch of the road.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p:
"She'll whip and gallop them!" there now!—this is one of the modern breed of
fine ladies, who, instead of being feminine and tender, have the Rage for confidence and bold
ness—Look at her dress—she's more like a man than a woman, and her language is as mascu
linè as her manners.

div.stage: Enter Lady SARAH SAVAGE dressed in a great coat, with a number of capes; a plain round beaver hat; a fur tippet and sash. Boot shoes, a whip in her hand, and a riding habit, under great coal; two grooms enter with her.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: John, exercise the pointers, and the hounds—I shall shoot to-morrow, and hunt the next day.

sp.speaker: Groom.
sp.p: Any thing else, madam?

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p:
No—nothing—Oh yes: call at the taylor's and enquire for my fencing jacket—tell him I broke two foils in my last rencontre, and ask him if any body ought to make assaults in a gown and petticoat?—Ah! my little dears—here (Seeing Mrs. Darnley and Clara, she makes them pull off her great coat, which the groom takes.) Well! and how do ye do? Oh Wil
liam!—tell the recruiting serjeant I must learn the new military manoeuvres, and bid him bring the largest fusil in the regiment—there—go along—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: I hope you have recover'd your fright, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Recover'd!—heh!—why, where's my deliverer!—my dear charming Mr. Darnley?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p:
He is certainly the most divine engaging creature—I mean to take him home
with me, and the Phaeton is waiting—so call him, child— (to Clara.) call him directly.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Call:—whom, madam?

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Why, Mr. Darnley, to be sure; what does the girl stare at?—did she never see a person of quality before.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Never—its the first time, ma'am; and if this is the specimen, I hope it will be the last:—I'll call Mr. Darnley.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p:
I wish I was like you, my dear—I wish I was married—its so comfortable—so con
venient—heigho!—I shall be so glad when old Sir Paul is my stalking horse—my husband I mean—shan't you, Mrs.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Excuse me, madam: when I reflect, that Sir Paul is Mr. Darnley's uncle, and by your union he is deprived of all his future fortune, you cannot blame me, if —

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Deprive my dear Darnley of his fortune!—so it does—well!—that's vastly droll!—but then it makes mine, which is the same thing you know—See!—here's my bear of a brother!—you've no idea what low, vulgar company he keeps?—nothing but Buffoons, Bow-street Officers, and Boxers!—and only conceive, my dear, me and my friends mixing in such horrid society.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Surely Mr. Savage cannot wish—

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p:
He does, ma'am: and only con
ceive I say my intimate acquaintance—people of the first consequence—such as Signor Cyg
net, the husband of the fine Soprano—Monsieur Puppitini, the inventor of the dear Fantoccini, and Count Spavin the greatest of Horse Doctors—only imagine such pick'd com
pany
as this, mixing with my brother's low-liv'd wretched crew.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Indeed, ma'am, people of rank ought to set a better example.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p:
So Savage—sister I mean—I lost ten pounds by your silly accident—The moment I saw the horses off, I said to my friends around me, ten pounds to five, the driver gets a tum
ble—"done!"—"it's a bett" says I—away flew the racers,—snap went the reins—five to four in my savour!—when plague on't! the Squire rode across, stopt the carriage—you sav'd your neck, and I—lost my wager.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p:
You brute: did you ever hear your brother, Lord Savage, talk in this man
ner?

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p:
My brother!—pough!—he's a gen
tleman to be sure—proud, independent, and all in the grandee style—but I!—I'm not like him—I'm a man of fashion—I'm not a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: No—that you are not upon my honour.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: I am the hero of my society—he is the slave of his—he keeps high company, ma'am (To Mrs. Darnley,) lives with judges, generals, and admirals—but does he ever encourage the arts and sciences? does he ever shake hands with men of genius? such as peace officers, tennis play'rs, and boxers—no, no—that was left for me.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Yes: and though born to wealth and titles, there you stand, that have been six times bottle holder at a boxing match!—vulgar science!—I hope Sir Paul don't understand it.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: No—not now—but if he makes you his wife, it may be necessary he should, learn,— I say, ma'am, that was a straight one—wasn't it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p:
Indeed I don't know, sir; —Wou'd Mr. Darnley were here!—I am unequal to their society; but from the lit
tle I have learnt, I think one hour of domes
tic life worth all this new unintelligible scene.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: Hark'ye: (to Lady Sarah,) here's a letter from the old beau, Sir Paul—he is coming to Bath, and can only stay one day with us, in his way; but as people of quality are not always people of quantity you know, he shan't stir, till the marriage is effected—mum!—I'll keep him close—

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: Ha! squire!—come Mrs. Darnley; (takes her by the hand.) I'll drive you and your pretty cousin—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Sir, I am unus'd to visiting; unfit—

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: Nonsense!—I never take an excuse; when I ask people to my house, I make them go when I like—stay while I like, and behave as I like—so come along—squire mind you don't snap the reins; and d'ye hear; as my sister is rather lame—only just recover'd from the gout—

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: The gout!—how dare you, sir?

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p:
What!—do you deny it?—do you disown having been our'd by a quack doctor, and returning him thanks in all the papers? Lady Sarah Savage informs Dr. Panacea, that his alagaronic antispasmodonic tincture, has entirely remov'd the gout from the extremi
ties,
and she now hunts, shoots, eats and drinks more freely than ever!—now isn't it a shame, ma'am? between them, they plun
der both the patient and the physician.—The quack cheats the doctor of his fee, and the woman robs the man of his gout.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p:
Oh, Mr. Darnley!—I am so glad you're going to Savage house—'twill be such a relief—come—I'll appoint you my rural Cicis
beo—my guardian shepherd—you sav'd my life, and I won't let you die for me, I am deter
min'd!

div.head:
SCENE I.—The Honourable Mr. SAVAGE'S Park and Garden—a Canal with a Vessel on it—a Bridge—a Temple surrounded with Weeping Wil
lows—at the Wing a Portico and Steps leading to the House.
div.stage: Enter DARNLEY and Sir GEORGE GAUNTLET from the Portico.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Why now indeed you are an alter'd man?

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: I am—I am—the wine—the scene —the company—has so transported me, that I begin to think I'm not quite sober, Sir George— I do indeed.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: No wonder at it—you've led the life of a recluse and every new scene dazzles you —you are like a nun escap'd from a convent.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p:
No—more like a Friar in one—at least if I may judge by my eating and drinking— But my friend—this is a glorious place, and I begin to think I've liv'd too long out of the world—coop'd up in a cottage—buried in a farm—What did I know of life and all its plea
sures?

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p:
Ay: what indeed?—in town—and Savage-house is the same thing you see; for they always bring London into the country with them —but Lady Sarah, Darnley—I saw you at din
ner;—she gave you such affectionate looks.—

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: Fie! fie Sir George—you forget— I am a married man.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: A married man!—what then!

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: Why then I love my wife—I do— I tenderly love her—and when I chuse to play the fool, let me expose myself, but not wound her for heaven's sake!

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Nonsense!—you don't know Lady Sarah—she is one of those confident females, who won't let a man escape—who mark you for their prey—lure you into their talons; and, if you don't yield, will so claw you.—

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: What! make me love her whether I will or not?

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p:
Certainly: but consider the ad
vantages of her friendship: first she can get you promotion in the army; secondly, by gaining an ascendancy over her, you may prevent her marrying your uncle; and thirdly, you can pro
vide for your family without injuring your ho
nour—there!—there's an opportunity!

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: That's true; and if I thought— hark'ye; as we're alone, and you're my best of friends—I've got a letter from her! the Signor brought it me—here! (taking out a letter.)—She appoints me to meet her in her dressing-room.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p:
Bravo, Signor!— (aside)—let's read. — (Reads the Letter.)— Lady Sarah Savage, having something particular to communicate to Mr. Darnley, begs to see him in her dress
ing-room in an hour's time.—Go by all means,—go, I insist.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p:
Why, if I can persuade her not to mar
ry Sir Paul, or even get her to interfere with him —I'll go!—I'm fix'd—I'll write to her this instant. He that essays no danger gains no praise!

div.stage: Enter the Honourable Mr. SAVAGE hastily.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p:
Joy! joy my lads! Sir Paul is arri
ved! and how do you think the old boy intro
duced himself to my porter?—"Tell your mas
ter, says he, a young gentleman desires to see him."

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p:
Young gentleman!—that's ex
cellent—he's at least seventy-two.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p:
No, you wrong him; he's only se
venty—Sir Paul Perpetual—Old P. I mean; for that's his nick name you know—has been the ancient beau of the age these thirty years, and as his great grief is, that he never had a son, he wants my consent to marry my sister.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: And do you mean to consent, sir?

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p:
Certainly—I say (aside to Sir George) —I want his fortune to repair my own, and therefore he shan't leave the house till the mar
riage is effected—you know my way.—I've given the hint to the servants.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Sir here's the young gentleman.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p:
Squire, take my place at the table— push the wine about, and tell the jovial crew to prepare for quizzing—quizzing you rogue!— go (Darnley exit)—the license is in my pocket, a parson's in the house, and if we can but con
fuse the young gentleman, we'll marry him in a joke, and afterwards take his fortune in earnest.

div.stage: Enter SIR PAUL PERPETUAL, in a riding dress.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: "Be lively, brisk and jolly!—lively, brisk and jolly!" (singing.) Ah, my boys!—here I am—as young and hearty—but I can't stay; I must be at Bath to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p:
At Bath!—what to drink the wa
ters? to renovate before marriage, Sir Paul.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p:
No—upon my soul there's no occa
sion—though, at present, perhaps a little physical advice wouldn't be much amiss: for between ourselves, I've just cut a tooth, and suffer'd most violently from the hooping cough! (They laugh) —Why what do you laugh at?

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p:
Nothing—nothing—only we won
der'd how such a chicken as you could struggle against a pair of such mortal disorders!—but, seriously—what takes you to Bath?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Such an event? I have trac'd a son; a boy above twenty years of age! that's my first reason—my second is—to see my grandfather.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: Your grandfather!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Hark'ye—he shall make settlements on my first four children.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Pray, Sir Paul—I beg your pardon though—what age may your grandfather be?

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: Two hundred, if he's an hour! heh? an't I right, old P.?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p:
Old P.! there it is now!—here I stand, that walk as much as any man—that ride as much as any man—that am every night at a concert, an opera, or a club—that sing, dance, game or intrigue! and what's more, that have done all this for sixty years!—and yet to be call'd
old P!—they said I never was a father—but I shall soon prove the great and glorious fact.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: Ay! how will you prove it?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p:
How! why you've all heard of my little Nelly—poor girl! she was jealous, and she left me to marry a tradesman—a clerk at a lot
tery office, and three months after we parted she was deliver'd of a boy—a fine boy! as like me as one Cupid is to another—a year after her marriage, she died, and I can hear nothing of her husband; but let him say what he will, I'll swear the boy was mine; I'll swear it, because I'm convinc'd I'm father to more children than one, Sir George.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Very likely; but where did you learn all this?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: From Nelly's sister; a month ago I accidentally met her at Tunbridge; she had neither seen nor heard of the husband since her sister's death, but she remember'd the child went by his mother's name! its mine!—I'm sure its mine! and (they laugh again.) I tell you what—you'd better be careful; for when you and other young sprigs of fashion smile at me, jeer me, and call me the infirm old P.!—'gad! you little think you dogs, you are laughing at your own father perhaps! however, I've trac'd my boy to Bath, and whoever discovers him shall have the too best racers in my stud.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: What fidget and fizgig? then I'll seek for young P. myself—I'll find him—I'll— but hold—hold— (Stopping Sir Paul who is going) don't go yet—your nephew's in the house.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p:
What Darnley?—zounds! then I won't stay a moment—no—not even to see my dear Lady Sarah, who I'll marry if its only to
disappoint that rural reprobate—that—I'm gone.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: No—you're not—I'll tell you a secret; you shall stay a week with me.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: A week!

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p:
Ay: I've my reasons—so don't think of stirring; for your horses are turn'd out to grass—your saddles and bridles snug in a hid
ing place, and all the gates double bar'd, inside and out.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: What the devil! make a prisoner of me?

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p:
Nonsense!—I only forestall your wishes:—I'm sure you want some soft discourses with my sister, and don't I know what my visi
tors like better than they do themselves? don't I know you like getting drunk?—so come; come in and drink!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: I don't—I hate drinking; and death and fire! haven't I told you I want to find my son—

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Humour him; humour him, Sir Paul; or he'll refuse you his sister.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: Ay: give consent, or else—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Or else I lose my wife I suppose; when I'm in the country, don't I like always to live quiet, and keep early hours, and would you lock me in a house where you never see the sun? where you go to bed just before it rises, and get up the moment after it sets?

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: Will you give up the marriage, and let Darnley have his wish?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: No—I'll die first—I'll—

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: Then will you join the jolly crew and prove—

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: That you have as much health, youth, and spirits—

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: As any choice spirit—

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Or young gentleman—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: In the whole world!—I'm rous'd! I'm fir'd! and to shew I'm season'd! true English heart of Oak!—allôns!

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: "Bring the flask! the music—

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: "Joy shall quickly find us—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: "Let us dance and laugh and sing, and drive old care behind us!"

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p:
Can this be the mansion of ele
gance and taste? I meet with nothing but rude
ness and neglect!—I wish I could find Mr. Darn
ley!—I dare say, by this time, he is sicken'd of the scene, and anxious as myself, to see his home again.

div.stage: Enter DARNLEY from the Portico, half drunk, with Lady Sarah Savage's letter in his hand.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p:
Fill away my boys!—fill!—fill!—while I like a faithful gal
lant!—gallant! hold, hold, friend Darnley. This letter is to benefit your interest, not sacrifice your honour.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Heavens!—what do I see? Mr. Darnley!

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: Yes:—you do; you see Mr. Darnley.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Why?—what's the matter with you!—what's that letter?

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: This letter?—this is a love letter, my angel,—ha!—why it is!—it is my wife!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Yes: that wife who in the hour of dissipation you forget—can I believe it?—in a little hour can all our past attachment—but why am I alarmed?—Fashion may dupe the wicked and the weak, but virtue such as his must scorn its empty power.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: Forget!—no never!—and now I look at you—I think I ought to be massacred for having even for a moment neglected you—Oh Maria!—I have such news for you—Lady Sarah has been so kind—she has promised to promote me—to befriend you—and in short she has taken a liking to the whole family.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: And why, Harry?

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p:
Why! ay: there's the rub! but don't be jealous, Maria—I entreat you, don't be jealous!—for by heaven, I love you!—I do so ten
derly that if it were not for my promise, I could find in my heart to return home directly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnly.
sp.p: Do; let us begone—the place distracts me: and I fear this high company will corrupt you.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: High company!—hang it:—if that's all you're afraid of, there's not much danger in this house I fancy—but my letter—my word to Sir George—and consider our interest, Maria.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p:
Oh no—consult our happiness my love; and surely there is none in this tumultu
ous scene—we left all joy behind us, in our children and our cottage, Harry; and there alone we shall recover it—come.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p:
She's right—the pretty prattler has reason on her side and who can disobey— (looks
without,) ha!—Sir George and Lady Sarah in close conversation!—they beckon me!—again!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Why do you pause?

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p:
I'm in for it—the die is cast!—Ma
ria!—excuse me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: How! will you leave me, Mr. Darnley?

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: What can I do?—'tis but for a short time.—
You must not.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: Nay: only for an hour.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.stage: (Letting him go and taking out her handkerchief.)
sp.p: —This is the first time you ever us'd me thus.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p:
So it is—now what a pretty scoun
drel I am!—and this is fashionable life is it?—Oh fool! fool! to quit substantial peace for artificial pleasure!—don't weep, Maria—I go for our mutual advantage—I go to make our chil
dren happy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Then stay with their mother—they never wish'd that we should part.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: Nor will we—we've liv'd so long and happily together, that I would rather lose the little we have left, than hurt your quiet.— (Enter Sir George Gauntlet.) Sir George stay with her—I'll see Lady Sarah, entreat her forgiveness, and return instantly; for, oh my friend!—my heart drops blood for every tear she sheds.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p:
P'sha!—remember your interest—Lady Sarah will soon reconcile your scruples, and leave me to compose Mrs. Darnley—nay: take your opportunity—you must keep the ap
pointment—I insist—so begone!— (Darnley exit.) What a fuss here is about a man's leaving his
wife for an hour, when so many worthy couple would be happy to part for ever.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Sir George, tell me, where is he gone? tell me, that I may fly and overtake him!

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Why! can't you guess?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: No, indeed, I cannot.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Not that he is gone to Lady Sarah to keep an assignation with her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: An assignation.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: In her dressing-room! at this very hour—the gay scene has so alter'd him, that you see he has left you to keep the appointment.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: I'll not believe it!—he is above such baseness.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Won't you?—then I'll prove it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: I defy you!—he knows the value of my heart too well to trifle with it; and I've known his so long, that I'll not venture to suspect it—no—though his friend defames it.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Nay then—you remember his hand-writing—here is his answer to the lady's letter—read.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Ha!—it is too plain—I am deceiv'd—deserted.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: I was the bearer of that letter, and preserv'd it merely to shew it you, I thought it the duty of a friend.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p:
And from the same duty, you advis'd him to write it.—Oh! I have known you long, Sir George—you are one of those who find no happiness but in marring that of others—who seduce the affections of the husband, the better to betray the honour of the wife! and when you've spoilt all social and domestic peace, the
friend you laugh at, and the woman scorn!—I know you well!

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: My dear ma'am, how you mistake!—I meant to oblige you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Sir—there is but one way—leave me—nay, I insist—

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: I shall obey.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p:
I must have stronger proof be
fore I am convinc'd, and then observe, Sir George, if his truth weakens, I'll add strength to mine! my constancy and honour shall be so ex
emplary, that I will shame him from his follies! make him repent: and when reclaim'd, be proud to say he is my own again!

div.head: SCENE II.—An elegant Apartment leading to Lady SARAH'S Dressing-Room—the Door in the Flat.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p:
Yes: yes: its all over the House—Sir George makes no secret of the assignation, and I've no doubt but Darnley is now in that room waiting for Lady Sarah Savage—she can't come at present—the servant says, she's gone to the stables to see the beasts unharness'd—faith! if she'd go to her brother's party she'd see that business already done!—however I'll pre
vent Darnley's exposing himself, and as he is certainly conceal'd in that room, I'll talk to him.—Dear!—here's my guardian again!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p:
So far, I'm safe, my dear girl; you don't know what your poor guardian has suf
fer'd in this high—no—this low-lif'd house!—they forc'd me into a room full of buffoons, boxers, and blacklegs—made me drink a bowl of punch, and I'd as soon drink so much poison—then winking and nodding they began whispering pretty loudly—"smoke the old prig!—damme, quiz him!"

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Quiz him!—what's that, Guardy?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p:
Why, with our young men of qua
lity, quizzing is a substitute for wit, my dear; so one man challeng'd me to play on the violin, and when I rose to move my elbows, another whip'd the chair from under me; a second put hot coals into my pocket, so when I felt for my hankerchief, I burnt my fingers; a third tried to cut off my tail, but that assassin I pursued, when unluckily in running after him, they had tied a string across the stairs, and I pitch'd headforemost into a barrel of water, they had placed for the purpose.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Indeed, its quite terrible, Gaurdy.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p:
Then they shew'd me a license; brought me a fat parson, and said, if I'd in
stantly be married, they'd let me go to find my son—if not, I should be lock'd in, and have plenty of it—now here's hospitality!—but they've overshot the mark; and if I get out of their doors, I'll not only break off the match, but promise to befriend Darnley.—

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p:
What! disappoint Lady Sarah, and relieve my poor distressed friend—then I'll get you out
of the house—I will, if I'm quizz'd to death for it—You see that door—if he meets Darnley, he'll at least interrupt the assignation.—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Secure my escape—only get me out of this den of savages, and, if I don't befriend Darnley, may I never live to see old age. Where does that door lead to?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p:
I fancy to Lady Sarah's dressing room; for it is full of half boots, horse great coats, mi
litary sashes, helmet caps, and amazonian jack
ets! and this is your only way to escape—enter that room.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Yes—

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p:
Put on one of Lady Sarah Savage's great coats, tie one of her sashes round your waist—throw a fur tippet about your neck, and with a whip in your hand, and her driv
ing hat on your head—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: I understand—the servants will take me for their mistress, and open the gates; Oh! you dear girl! (kisses her.)—I'll about it instantly— (opens the door in flat.) I say, Clara, the hounds below are unkennel'd; they have started me for game, and after keeping them at bay, by sousing in a flood of water, I take to cover; that is, I put on Lady Sarah Savage's cloathes to avoid passing for a wild beast; mum!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: If he does but get out of the house, the marriage is broken off and Darnley made happy.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah Savage
sp.p: I'm at home to nobody but Mr. Darnley.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: We're undone, ruin'd; stay where you are; here's Lady Sarah.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: —The devil!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p:
Hush! lock yourself in, and don't stir till I tap at the door, or stop—stop—lest she or somebody else should tap, don't open it till I give you a signal—let me see; what shall be the watchword? Oh, "quizzing," you won't for
get "quizzing," Guardy.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: No—I shall remember it these fifty years; so when I hear the word "quizzing," out I come, and—softly—here she is

div.stage: Enter Lady SARAH, with pocket-book and tickets in her hand.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Tell my dear Signor, I shall get rid of all these benefit tickets; heh! (taking out her spying glass.)—what young creature's this?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: How d'ye do again ma'am?

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Again! you're vastly forward child; I never saw you before.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p:
No ma'am! that's very strange; you saw me this morning at Mr. Darnley's, and in
vited me to your house.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Oh, ay: now I recollect; you must excuse me; we people of rank are so very absent; we're extremely intimate with a person in the morning, and don't know them at night; well! I'm vastly glad to see you; but you mustn't stay here, I'm engaged child.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: I shan't intrude, ma'am—good day.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Adieu! stop—stop—I forgot; give me two guineas.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Two guineas, ma'am!

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p:
Yes: for these tickets; they're for the Signor's wife's benefit at Bath next Mon
day,
the whole town will be there—nay, I shall at
tend—I'd make you take more, but as you'll have to pay card money bye and bye, it would be asking you to one's house absolutely to make a bargain of you! (Clara gives the two guineas.) there—you may go.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p:
A bargain indeed! and a bad one too: for if I was mean enough to make money by my guests, would I lay it out on foreigners who loll in carriages? no—not while so many of our gallant soldiers and sailors have only wooden limbs to stand on! (half aside.) I am gone, ma'am, (curtseying.) and now may Darnley get out of the scrape—Sir Paul get out of the house—and she and her brother knock their stupid heads to
gether.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: I suppose this silly creature has interrupted the charming Mr. Darnley, and he has stept into my dressing room— (goes to the door and finds it fasten'd.)—lock'd inside—it must be so— (listens)—I declare I hear him moving; (she listens again)—he sighs!—poor man! (she speaks loudly.)—don't be dejected, my dear sir; when I'm married to that old tottering beau, Sir Paul, I'll think of nothing but you. So come, Mr. Darnley, (Enter Mrs. Darnley,) come my sweet Mr. Darnley.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p:
Can it be possible?—then all's confirm'd madam, when I am convinced that my husband—that Mr. Darnley has been de
coyed into that room.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p:
Bless me!—its Mrs. Darnley!—this is a little aukward—how
ever I'll soon talk her out of it, (aside.) Don't be uneasy, my dear—these fashionable intrigues are
very harmless, I'll assure you, and if you had had my free and liberal education—but poor thing! I suppose you were sent to school for instruction.

sp.speaker: Mr. Darnley.
sp.p: To school! as certainly ma'am—

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: There it is then: for what could you learn! only to sing well enough to spoil conversation—to play on the harpsichord, so as to give papa, mama, and the whole family an afternoon's nap—to dance so aukwardly as to be always out of tune and place; and to speak just French enough, to make you forget English; this is a boarding school education—But I my dear—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p:
Hear me, madam! when I first saw you, I was the happiest of women—I had a husband who lov'd and honour'd me—who doat
ed on his children, and knew no pleasure but in his family! and now how severe is the reverse! you have robb'd me of that treasure, seduc'd it from my heart, and I return to a melancholy home, without a friend for my own distresses, or a father for my children!

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: And how can I help it?—didn't I mean to do you both a service by introducing you to the great world?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p:
Great world!—there again, madam!—when I enter'd this house, I expected from the exalted rank of its owner to have been surrounded with kindness, elegance, and hospita
lity!—but I find that high birth doesn't create high breeding, nor am I, because humbly born, less likely to set a polish'd example than yourself—Oh Darnley! why will you not come forth and save your once lov'd wife from agonies too great to bear.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: So Savage—here's a pretty story buzz'd about!—they say that Darnley, the country 'squire, is lock'd up in your dressing-room! if this is true you Jezabel—

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p:
Scandalous brute!—but I don't wonder at it, you've had such a low vulgar educa
tion.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: I had an education!—well that's more than ever you had!—but look'ye, Miss, no time must be lost; for if Sir Paul discovers your intriguing, he'll break off the marriage, and we are ruin'd—yes; ruined madam! (to Mrs. Darnley,) you and your infamous husband will make your own plots and marr mine—so I'll unkennel him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Hold, sir—indeed he is not to blame—he was betray'd into that room.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p:
Betray'd!—nay, then I must con
fess, brother, that Mr. Darnley is there; I dare say he conceal'd himself on purpose to expose me to Sir Paul—nay, I am sure of it now.

sp.speaker: Savage,
sp.p:
I see him through the key-hole—the rascal's in disguise! (enter two servants.) John call up the club—un
loose the hounds—tell the whole house to pre
pare for quizzing—quizzing, you rogue.—

div.stage: Sir PAUL dress'd in Lady SAVAGE'S Great Coat, &c. opens the door, endeavours to escape, but meeting Mr. SAVAGE retires again directly.

sp.speaker: Savage
sp.p: —John, open the back-door, and shew the disguis'd gentleman out of the house directly—go—and as for you Mrs. Darnley—

div.stage: DARNLEY enters, and Mrs. DARNLEY, Lady SARAH, and SAVAGE, stand astonished.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: Confusion!—Darnley!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p:
Is he then innocent?—Oh Har
ry!

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Amazing! why, who was that wretch in my coat, hat, and tippet!

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: No less a gentleman than Sir Paul Perpetual—Clara told me the whole story—he put on that disguise to avoid the snares that were laid for him, and he has ere this left the house, determined to break off an union, that would have undone me and my family—lady Sarah, I entreat your pardon; but here (taking Mrs. Darnley by the hand,) here is my apology.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p:
Sir, I have shewn the disguis'd gentle
man down stairs.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: Go to the devil with you.—

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Brother!

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: Sister!

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p:
We are the fools that are out
witted.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p:
Yes: we've turn'd out the wrong man—but let's pursue and overtake him instant
ly; come,—'squire, I insist you leave my house directly, and as to you Miss—if I catch the young gentleman, I'll have some sport, I'm de
termined—I'll turn you both loose amongst the hounds below, and the Club shall decide, whe
ther
ther old P. isn't the prettiest looking female of the two!

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p:
I resolved, Maria, to meet any cen
sure, rather than give a pang to such a heart as yours; but let us be gone—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Ay: let us return to our villa, nor ever wander more.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: No—not yet Maria.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Not yet!

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: No—I have a plan to execute—Sir George, my best of friends, has invited us both to his aunt's house at Bath, and is now waiting without to conduct us.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Do not go! let me entreat you; do not—I have a thousand fears.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: Nay, nay: he will introduce us to friends, who can render us essential service; come—come—indulge me—the society will be pleasant, and unlike this ill-bred scene—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p:
Well! if it must be so—Ah, Har
ry! I have now pass'd hours in the humble and exalted scenes of life, and I find that good breed
ing is confin'd to no rank or situation! it consists in good sense, and good humour, and I believe we may see as large a share of it under the roof of the cottage, as in the splendid mansions of the great!

div.head:
SCENE I.—A superb room in FLUSH'S house; handsome sideboard of Plate—Pictures in elegant Frames—gilded chairs—two servants in fine live
ries, putting silver coffee pot, tea urn, &c. on the table for breakfast, a third servant shewing in READY.

sp.speaker: Ready.
sp.p: Tell your master, his agent desires to see him.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Sir, Mr. Flush is hardly drest yet.

sp.speaker: Ready.
sp.p: Not up!—why it's two o'clock.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Very likely, sir—my master seldom rises sooner—besides he gave a grand supper last night; all the first people in Bath were present, sir.

sp.speaker: Ready.
sp.p:
Well! well! tell him Mr. Ready is here: (Servant exit.) now isn't it amazing that a man who was only twelve years ago clerk to a lottery-office-keeper in London, should be so rich, and so visited, and how has he done all this? how, but by the modern mystery of money lending!—by opening a shop in the city for li
nens, gauzes; and muslins—by keeping a fine house near Bond street, and another in Bath. His son manages in London, and I here, while he by not appearing, is every where noticed and respected.

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: James! Thomas! tell the cook to send a plan of my dinner.

sp.speaker: Ready.
sp.p: He's such an epicure! and he, who formerly could scarcely get necessaries, is now not satisfied with luxuries.

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: Ha! Ready! how d'ye do, Ready?

sp.speaker: Ready.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: Sit down, Ready—sit down. (Ready sits.) well! how go on money matters?

sp.speaker: Ready.
sp.p: I have alter'd the advertisement as you desir'd, and inserted it in the Bath and Bristol papers.

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p:
Read it—read it. (Takes up a pine ap
ple on the breakfast table) You scoundrels! (to the servants.) is this a pine apple for a gentleman? buy a larger; buy one if it costs ten pounds; I can afford it—read, Ready, read.

p.q:
Money mat
ters!—the nobility, gentry, ladies of fashion, officers of rank, bankers, &c. may be secretly accommodated with money to any amount, on personal security only, by applying to P. O. Holly Street, Bath—No. 93.

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: Excellent! well! does the trap fill! have you caught any birds?

sp.speaker: Ready.
sp.p: Plenty; plenty of pigeons already; (Takes out his pocket-book.) here, here's a note for five hundred—left by a dashing young parson—I think it's good.

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: It is—treat him well; give him value; I can afford it.

sp.speaker: Ready.
sp.p: Value! but in what manner, Sir?

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p:
Oh! pay him in the old way, Ready; first, give him my draft at a week for
thirty guineas, then offer him damag'd linen and muslin to the amount of one hundred and twenty, and bid him call again in a fortnight—you have his note all the time you know.

sp.speaker: Ready.
sp.p: Certainly, sir; and when he calls—

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: Give him a bad bill for one hundred and fifty, and pay him the odd hundred in trifles; such as paste buckles, gilt bracelets, Westphalia hams, painted prints, neats tongues, and Stilton cheeses—so shake hands, and have done with Master Parson.

sp.speaker: Ready.
sp.p: But not with the bill, sir.

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p:
No—my bankers discount it, and pay it away, till passing through different hands, somebody gives value for it at last, and then the glorious work begins—then comes the hero into combat! an attorney is employ'd! an attorney, my boy! action is brought upon action! decla
ration filed upon declaration! till the drawer, acceptor, and indorsers all get into the King's Bench—the King's Bench—no—I beg pardon; the high money-lenders, and low attornies, have so fill'd it, with their dupes, that there isn't room there—the house overflows! so Newgate, Newgate is the shop!

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Here's your son! just arriv'd from London!

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: Shew him in.

sp.speaker: Ready.
sp.p: I'm told, sir, Mr. Gingham is quite another man, since I saw him.

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p:
Yes, yes, you knew his curst, ingenu
ous, candid disposition; he learnt it in the coun
try, the dog would speak the truth, and his sim
plicity
so injur'd our trade, that I threatened to turn him out of doors; but he has reform'd Ready! the boy has the good sense to tell a lie now, and I've sent for him to witness his blessed reformation.

sp.speaker: Ready.
sp.p: Ay, sir, your son always spoke his mind too freely—in short, Mr. Gingham was too honest for his profession.

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p:
He was; however he has given me his word, never to speak what comes uppermost, and he is now what he ought to be; a regular, so
lemn, jesuitical—in short—he's a very promising young man.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Sir, your hand—Ready yours, well! here I am—quite converted—like father, like son—tell a lie without blushing.

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: Here—I told you so—ay, ay, I knew the boy would come to something good at last—so my dear boy you've left off telling the truth—speaking your mind.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Mum! close as the cabinet—keep you in my eye—put on your face, and do it so punctually, you wouldn't know young P. O. from yourself— (Looking about the room,) zounds! what a fine house you've got! how its furnish'd! what plate! what pictures!

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: The result of trade and honest industry, Frank—yes—its pretty furniture isn't it?

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Pretty furniture! it's so handsome, that except yourself, curse me, if I see a shabby bit in the room!—nay, nay, upon my soul, I didn't allude to you; I meant Ready.

sp.speaker: Ready.
sp.p: He's at his old tricks I see—as candid as ever.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Plague on't! I could sooner bite off my tongue, than stop its speaking what I think! nay, sir, now pray.

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: Well, well, I excuse you this once; I, a shabby bit! however we shall soon see—how goes on the shop in London?

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: The shop!

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: Ay, the shop in the city that you've the care of—the linens—the—

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Oh ay: now I recollect; why very well upon the whole, I believe, sir—very well—only between ourselves; I'm afraid it won't last; I think we and our tricks shall be found out—you understand—

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: Found out! 'sblood, sirrah—

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p:
Softly sir—softly—don't put yourself in a passion, and lay the blame on me; don't charge me with our ruin, for every body knew my opinion long ago; didn't they, Ready? I told it to a thousand people—says I, "swind
ling will never thrive, and I and my poor fa
ther shall get duck'd at last!"

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: You did! did you?

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p:
That I did, sir; and I'll prove I said so—the other night I slept at the west end, and two friends—distress'd old officers in the army—brought their notes to be discounted—says I, Gentlemen, it won't do—you'll get little cash, but a quantity of trumpery nonsense, such as hams, cheeses, prints, linens, and other ve
getables! said they; we know that—we know you and your father are two infernal sharpers, but a guinea now is worth ten a month hence—so give us the money.

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: Well: and you took their note, didn't you?

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p:
No, I didn't—I gave them the cash, shook the two old soldiers by the hand, and said I was tir'd of such d—d swindling prac
tices.

sp.speaker: Ready.
sp.p: This is sad work, Mr. Gingham you'll never be at the top of your profession.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: The top!—Oh! what the pillory? no—I leave that to you, Ready!

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: Was there ever such a scoundrel?—but we'll hear more, (aside.)—So, you sleep at the west end of the town, do you?

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Always—its vulgar to be in the city of an evening; besides I like to walk in Kensington-gardens in the morning—You know Kensington-gardens, father—the place where there's such a mixture of green leaves and brown powder—of blue violets and yellow shoes; and where there's such a croud, that to get air and exercise you stand a chance of broken bones and suffocation!—Well!—there I strut away, my boys—

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: You do—do you?—I can hardly keep my hands off the rascal—So then I suppose, the moment my back was turn'd, you never thought of business.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p:
Business!—no never—Did I, Ready? I recollected my father play'd the same game before me; that when he was clerk at the lottery-of
fice, at billiards all the morning, and at hazard all the evening—therefore, says I, where's the diffe
rence?—none! but that he had the policy to conceal his tricks, and I the folly to shew mine—heh! I'm right—an't I, Ready?

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p:
You villain!—is this your reformation? not even conceal your own faults, much more
mine. Expose my character, neglect my trade, and strut away in Kensington-gardens! I have done with you from the country you came, and to the country you shall return—Speak the truth, indeed! zounds! sirrah, what has truth to do with money lending!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Oh, Guardy—I'm just come to Bath with Mr. and Mrs. Darnley—we are all on a visit at Sir George Gauntlet's, and—

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: Its only my son, Clara—a simple foolish young man.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: More knave than fool, upon my honour, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: The gentleman don't praise himself I see, Mr. Flush.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p:
No, ma'am—nor do I know any bo
dy that will praise me—unless my father indeed.

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p:
Silence, sir!—well: but about the ru
ral pair, my dear ward; do you know I have a great regard for Mr. and Mrs. Darnley.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Have you? I'm vastly glad of that for your joint guardian, Sir Paul, is so employ'd in seeking for his lost child, that he has forgot his promise to assist Darnley; therefore I want you to do him a favour.

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: A favour!—he may command me.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p:
The case is this—his increase of family has so enlarg'd his expences, that he has thoughts of returning to the army—Sir George has pro
mised to procure him a company, but Mrs. Darnley, not chusing he should owe his promo
tion to him, wishes he should purchase; now,
Guardy, if you would lend him two hundred pounds.

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: Two hundred pounds, child!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Ay, two hundred pounds, father!

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: Who bid you speak, sir?—Why, Clara, in money matters there is an etiquette.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: True: but this is your friend.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: So it is, ma'am: the man he has a great regard for.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: And when you consider the charms of Mrs. Darnley, and the wants of her children—

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: He can't refuse, ma'am—indeed he don't intend it—and therefore as I see he means to grant the favour, I'll save him the trouble of putting his hand in his pocket—Here, ma'am! (taking out bank notes) here are two bank notes of a hundred each—they belong to Mr. Flush—now they belong to Mr. Darnley— (Flush gets in his way and prevents Clara's taking them.)—he begs you'll give them to his friend—and present his compliments—and say, he'll double the sum.

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: Stand off—stand off—or by heavens I'll—

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.stage:
(Offering Clara the notes across his fa
ther)
sp.p: Double the sum, whenever call'd upon, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p:
Hold your tongue, or I'll knock it down your throat, sirrah.—I say, Clara, in the the way of business, I've no objection to do Mr. Darnley a service; that is, if I can make a pro
fit by it—first, he should send me his note.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Here it is, sir.

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: That's right—now we can proceed—here, sir— (Giving the note to Gingham,) take the note to my agent, and tell him to give Mr. Darnley thirty pounds—I can afford it.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: This is too bad—take in his own friend, and a man with a family, (aside.) Sir,—a word if you please—I told you, we were all blown upon—now, here's an opportunity for retrieving our reputation—lend him the two hundred pounds—prove, for once, we can behave like gentlemen, and hark'ye—we shan't reach the top of the profession.

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p:
This is beyond bearing—quit the room directly—'sdeath!—leave my house, sir—be
gone!—I disinherit you—I—

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Lord!—why so angry, guardian?—I'm sure he is a good young man, and as warm in his heart—

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: Warm in his heart!—nonsense!—will he be warm in the funds? no—never—while he is so candid—so—

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Not while he is candid, sir?

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: No—do you think I made my fortune by candour or openness; answer me, sir—did I ever get a shilling by speaking the truth— speak!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: No, sir, I never said you did—I know the contrary, sir; madam, I'm of a communicative disposition, I own; but there are many secrets of my father's I never blabb'd.

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: Are there, sir?

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Yes, that there are, sir.

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: I don't recollect them.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p:
Don't you? Why, now, did I ever mention, sir, that you got these pictures by sue
ing out execution? That you got that plate, by its being pawn'd to you for half its value; that you intrigue with a female money-lender; and that the last time you were made a bankrupt,
you went to get your certificate signed in a new vis-a-vis? did I, or will I ever mention these things?

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: Begone, sir—I'll never see you more— Yet, stay—you have papers in your possession —meet me in an hour's time at my agent's, sir, —at Mr. Ready's.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Forgive me this once, father—I'll never let the cat out any more.

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: No, sir, I never will forgive you— I am engaged, sir, and you know we great men are select in our company.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p:
Well, if it must be so—farewell, father! the world is all before me, and what trade to follow, heaven only knows. Good bye, madam!—your sex will never befriend me, be
cause I can't keep a secret, you see.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p:
I will befriend you, sir; for while there is so much deception and hypocrisy in the world, it would indeed be unjust, not to ap
prove such frankness and honesty. Guardy, let me intercede for him; I'll answer for his con
duct.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p:
Aye; and if ever I mention duck
ing or swindling again.—There! you see he's fix'd, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p:
At present he is, and therefore leave him, perhaps by the time you meet him at the agent's I shall have talked him into good humour. Adieu! depend on't, I shan't forget your gene
rous intentions.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p:
Nor shall I, yours; and if fortune smiles on me, I'll prove that I deserve your kindness—If ever my father pardons—but I see he's more and more angry, so I take my leave. May every blessing attend you—may you meet with a heart as liberal as your own—May your
cousins' distresses vanish—may your guardian once more value a son, who can't help speaking the truth for the soul of him.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Upon my word he's a charming man! and pardon him you must, Guardy, if its only to please me.

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: No—I'm determined.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: The dinner's ready.

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: Come, Clara, you shall dine with me; I want to talk to you, and if I cou'd see my joint Guardian, Sir Paul—

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: I met him at your door—he's only just gone by.

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: Just gone by! that's a mistake; for the old beau has been gone by these thirty years: however, come in—come, and eat and drink what you like. Call for burgundy, champagne, or tokay—Ay, call for tokay at a guinea a pint; I can afford it, my dear Ward, I can afford it.

div.head: SCENE II.—The Crescent and the surrounding country.
div.stage: Enter Lady SARAH SAVAGE, and Sir GEORGE GAUNTLET.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Sir George, I own my weakness: the proud, the haughty lady Sarah is humbled; Darnley has ensnared my heart, and one way or other, I must insure his pity—Heigho! you are his friend, Sir George.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: You see I am; and that he esteems me more than ever, is evident from his bringing Mrs. Darnley to my house—did you mind his orders to her?—take an airing my dear with Sir George in his phaeton! it will raise your spirits, my love!—Ha! ha! he absolutely throws her into my arms.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Yes; but she absolutely contrives to get out of them again.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: She does; and therefore, there is no way but the one I mentioned—we must make Darnley jealous.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: True:—I'll tell him that you love his wife.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p:
Nay, nay, not me—fix on some
body else—we'll soon find an object, and then by convincing him of her falsehood, he naturally turns his thoughts to another woman; which is you, you know—and she wanting a protector, consequently flies to another man, which is me, you know we'll add the Signor to the confede
racy.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: You're a sad wretch—a sad wretch indeed, Sir George, to impose on a friend, who places such confidence—such—I won't hear you—positively I won't hear you—only observe, if I don't win the cruel Darnley's affections, I'll drive my Phaeton down a precipice in reality; I will, or with the bayonet of my fusil, pierce my too tender heart, and expire at his feet.

div.stage: Enter the honourable Mr. SAVAGE hastily.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: So Sarah—I and Sir Paul have had such an adventure!—though we quarrel'd last night, we made it up to day; for I never think alike two hours together—Do you, sister?

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Never: but when I think of you brother, then I think more than I say, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: No; you say more than you think, I assure you—but would you believe it? The old boy has seen his son,—we trac'd him from the stage coach he came in, to the pump room, from the pump room, to the billiard room—there Sir Paul saw him playing with the marker, and when he heard the young man's name, he fainted; actually fainted in my arms.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: What, in a fit! poor old man! well! if you'll believe me, Sir George, I never saw a person in a fit in all my life.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: Long before he recover'd, the young man was gone—the bird was flown—for the standers by, all blacklegs began laying betts on Sir Paul's recovery, and those who were against him, wouldn't let water be thrown in his face.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Inhuman wretches!—they ought to have sous'd him to death: but pray, brother, who is this child? where does he come from? what's the story?

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p:
Why—about twenty years ago, Sir Paul's lady quarrell'd with him at Tunbridge, and married a citizen—Four months after the mar
riage she had a son, which the citizen brought up as his own, and Sir Paul now swears the boy was his—'gad! it will be curious; for the child will have two fathers.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Curious! not at all—but why should you meddle?

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p:
Because it secures me the two best racers in his stud—Fidget and Fizgig; and what's better, because it still secures us Sir Paul's fortune: for though he won't marry you him
self, he intends his son should; and, if I could but once more see the young man—I know he goes by his mother's name— (Looking out) heh! its him! there he is again!—get out of the way; don't interrupt—

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p:
No—I have too great a regard for Sir Paul's property to interrupt any plan for securing it; besides, Sir George and I have bu
siness—come—I say brother, tell the old gentle
man to be careful, and in his eagerness bid him not claim another man's child instead of his own!

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: Where can Sir Paul be loitering? he said he'd follow me—mum!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p:
Oh! what a whirligig world is this? I that was brought up to lend money; must now try to borrow it: but where? who'll trust a wan
dering linen-draper! who'll trust the notorious young P. O.? however, Iv'e got my equivalent; I can speak my mind now—no longer need I smother my thoughts, and be ready to burst: no longer have an itching on my tongue, and be ready to bite it in two—no, no, I may open now. The sweet lady sends me word my father is inex
orable, but hopes she shall soon see me again; heigho! I hope so too; when I think of her, my heart feels such queer sensations—I have it: she has taken lessons of my father, and swindled me out of my affections; but then my poverty— I can never indulge even a hope.— (Sees Mr. Savage.)—Ha! here's the friend of the queer old gentleman, who fainted in the billiard room.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p:
Sir, the honour
able Henry Savage has the pleasure—the feli
city—What are you—

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: the honourable?

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: Ay: why didn't you know it?

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: No: nor never should if you hadn't told me—ha! ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! you're a droll dog! 'gad! you shall come to my house, and pass a week with me.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p:
Faith! a year with all my soul! I've nothing to do with myself; I've left off trade; haven't change for sixpence in the world,
and so my little right honourable—I'll honour you with my company.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: Hush! if you want money don't own it: we great people are close—

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: I know it; oeconomical too!—you live cheap.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: What! people of fashion live cheap?

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: To be sure; you don't pay; and if that isn't living cheap, the devil's in't!—ha! here's the fainting gentleman again!—who the deuce is he?

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p:
I fancy you'll find him a pretty near relation of yours—at least, if you were born at Tunbridge, and your mother's name was Ging
ham.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: It was; that's the name of her, and of the town.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p:
Say you so?— (Enter Sir Paul Perpe
tual,)—The racers are mine, Sir Paul!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Ay: my whole stud—any thing: every thing! only let me have another peep at my dear boy!—only let me prove to posterity!

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: There he is!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Where!

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: There! there is your son! who was born at Tunbridge—whose mother's name was Gingham, and who is now without a shilling in his pocket, or a friend in the world—joy! joy! old boy! you've got a young P. at last!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Stand off! let me come at him; come to thy father's arms!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: My father!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p:
Ay: thy real father! who has a for
tune to bestow on thee, and health, youth, and spirits to share in all thy pleasures—The dog has my right eye to a T.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Pray does your friend bite in his fits?

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: Hark'ye—its Sir Paul Perpetual! better known by the name of old P.—he has an immense property.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Has he?

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p: Yes: and if its certain you are his son, he'll give you every farthing of it.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Oh! if that's the case—if he has an immense property—let me see who dare deny it? Sir, your blessing!— (kneeling.)—I always said I wasn't my father's own child.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Rise my boy! my darling! and tell us how the citizen educated you!—The turn of my nose exactly!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: I've done with linens, gauzes, and muslins now!—let the shop and all its swindling go to the bottom—I'm the son of Sir Paul Perpetual, better known by the name of old P. I'm not a tradesman —.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p:
Tradesman!—zounds!—my son brought up in a shop! — how it freezes my warm blood!—look'ye, my boy—two things I must re
quest of you—never to talk about trade, or men
tion your former father's name.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Never—I'll never mention his name because I despise it; but as to trade, what's bred in the bone, you know father —

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p:
Well—well—come to Mr. Savage's house; there we'll introduce you to your in
tended wise—Miss Savage will soon break you of talking about trade, or the city—so come along.

sp.speaker: Savage.
sp.p:
Ay: pray give up the city—the rich rogues have no taste for us men of wit and ge
nius—they estimate every thing by property,
and if the great Ben Jonson—nay, if the great Big Ben were alive, is there one citizen would give the poor dogs a dinner?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p:
No—you're right there; in the ci
ty a man that has no money, has no wit—the smallest bank note is more entertaining than the wittiest manuscript; and talk of Ben Jonson's name for jokes—damme, Abraham Newland beats him hollow! isn't it true, my boy?

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: As true, as that you beat my other father hollow—come—henceforth, no money lending tricks for me. But young P. O. shall stick to gay old P.

div.head: SCENE I.—A Drawing-Room in Mr. SAVAGE'S House at Bath.
div.stage:
Enter Sir GEORGE GAUNTLET and Signor CYG
NET.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Bravo! Signor bravissimo!—and so Lady Sarah Savage has actually persuaded Darnley, that his wife loves another man?

sp.speaker: Signor.
sp.p: Si—at first he no believe—but Lady Sarah lay it down with such courâge—her oaths were so superbe, and mine so magnifique, that 'at last he accompany us with tears—pauvre Mister Darnley!—Ah! ha!—you no forget my vife's concert.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p:
And who did you say Mrs. Darn
ley was attached to?

sp.speaker: Signor.
