sp.p: Attendez—Sir Paul—what you call—old P.—he has found one child—eh bien!—the enfant was at the comedie, and saw Madame Darnley and her 'cousin maltraité by some qu'on appelle bobbies—villains who fight de duels, and interrupt de music—Vell! de child relieve de ladies, conduct them home—sup, and dough all de time he make love to Mad'moiselle Clara—

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Yet, Lady Sarah Savage fixes on him for Mrs. Darnley's gallant—excellent! and if this scheme fails, I understand she has another—there is Mr. Flush—a sort of money agent.

sp.speaker: Signor.
sp.p: Je connois—je connois—he make a you poor, by lending you cash.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: This Mr. Flush has got Darnley's note for two hundred pounds—now he can't pay it; and therefore if Lady Sarah Savage buys it up—

sp.speaker: Signor.
sp.p: Je comprehende—she say, give me my heart, or pay me my money—ah ha!—I see you will be the first fiddle yourself;— (looking out.) le voici!—here is Mr. Flush!

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: No—it's Sir Paul and the son you spoke of—good day Signor—and if you see Darnley, tell him I'm out of town.

sp.speaker: Signor
sp.p: I vill! — ecoutez—I no like to meet this Sir Paul—ven he ask me to his house, he always sing himself—toujours—if he has de cold—de sore throat—il chante! and begar: he sing as well with the hoarseness, as without—bon-jour, Sir George—bon-jour— (going, recollects and turns back.) Ah ha!—you no forget my vife's concert?

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Darnley, jealous of his wife! and she under my own roof!—now, if I can persuade her to retaliate—here's her supposed gallant.

div.stage: Enter Sir PAUL and GINGHAM, elegantly dressed.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: I tell you, father, Clara Sedley is the girl of my heart!—your ward is the girl for young P.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p:
Nonsense!—haven't I made you a gentleman—stuck a sword by your side?—haven't I brought you here to address Lady Sarah Sa
vage?—ha! Sir George!—now mind (to Ging
ham) and conceal your low education—not a word about trade or the warehouse; for I mean to put you into the army, and I've told every
body you've been on your travels.—Sir George!—my son!

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Sir, I'm very proud of the honour.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Sir!—I'm very proud of— (bowing up to him, and spying at his chitterlin)—right India muslin, by all that's—mum!

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: You've been a great traveller, sir,—much abroad?

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Abroad!—yes, sir—I was seldom at home—generally at the West End, for between ourselves, though I was brought up to trade, I always despis'd the warehouse—always—pshaw!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Zounds!—mind what you're at—consider, if you talk as my son, about linens and the warehouse, they'll take your father for a tradesman; they'll say I'm a haberdasher, knighted on a city address!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: A haberdasher!—that's a good one, a very good one—upon my soul; Sir George, my father is'nt such a fool, as you take him for—no—that he isn't—are you, father?

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah Savage.
sp.p: When Mr. Flush comes, shew him up stairs.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Here's your intended wife, sir—'gad! I hope it will be a match, for Lady Sarah is so anxious for a husband, that in the scramble, she might seize me at last—come, Sir Paul—let's leave the happy pair together.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Now, remember what I told you—Lady Sarah is the essence of fashion and good breeding; and if you want to polish, and rub off the city-rust, imitate her—copy her elegant manner.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p:
Ay: she's the rage!—and, if he wants to secure her affections, bid him imitate
his father, Sir Paul—copy you, and he must succeed with the women.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p:
Ay, that he must, Sir George—there's not a girl at Newmarket, not a dancer at the opera, or a singer at the ancient concert, but adores me—they treat me with the same re
spect they would a father—they say I'm so quiet—so inoffensive—so harmless.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p:
Harmless! do they say you're harm
less, father?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p:
Ay, harmless, and under that idea, I've done more mischief, then any ten danger
ous men in Europe—So copy her manners, and success to you, my boy!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p:
Bravo! these are fine times, Mas
ter Gingham,—but will they last?—is there no trick play'd, or to be play'd thee?—Sir Paul I'm told has a way of disguising himself in women's cloathes, surely this is'nt another mas
querading affair—Ah! here's spouse!—now to imitate her fashionable manners.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Marry him, I will: because in the first place, there's a scarcity of husbands; and in the next, being his wife, secures Sir Paul's fortune, and makes Darnley for ever in my pow'r—besides, I can draw the youth into all my schemes—hem!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Hem! (imitating her.) If this is a woman of fashion, the breed is grown pretty bold I think.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p:
I must shew him my spirit—ter
rify him before marriage, in order to tame
him after. (Going towards him wriggling her head.) Sir!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Ma'am.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Give me a chair!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: A chair, ma'am?

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Yes, a chair, sir.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Essence of breeding!—she's the essence of brass! (brings her a chair.) A chair, ma'am!

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: He little knows what a life I shall lead him.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Heh!—a chair, ma'am!—here's a chair, I say—

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p:
Oh, I forgot—I am really so ab
sent— (sits down) he! he! he!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Are you really!—he! he! he!—I should like to— (mimicking) imitate her manners! hang me if I dare—she has set me all in a tremble—pheugh!
sp.stage: (Puffing himself with his hat, and drawing his chair from her.)

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p:
Look up, my hero! (slapping him.) You can't think how I rejoice at your be
ing designed for the army. I'm of a military, mar
tial turn myself, and shall serve every campaign with you.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: You serve campaigns!—I wish I was out of the room—pheugh!

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p:
I shall make an excellent sol
dier—a dauntless warrior! and if you talk of little unfledg'd fluttering ensigns, look at me—look!— (shaking him) march!—wheel about!—left!—make ready!—present!—fire!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.stage: (Looking first at her feet, then at her head.)
sp.p: It is—it is an impostor!—ugh!

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p:
Shan't I make a warlike appear
ance! animate one army, and intimidate ano
ther? restore the name of amazon—revive the age of chivalry, and if there are fools that threaten, and cowards that dread an invasion; Oh! how the thought fires me!— (rises,)—give me a few champions like myself, and we'll stand on our white cliffs, and scare away whole na
tions.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p:
Damme, it's another man in wo
man's cloathes! don't agitate yourself—be com
pos'd— (to her as she walks about.) what would I give to be snug behind the counter?

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p:
I am no timid helpless woman; I can shoot—I can fence—flourish a sword, or fire off a musket!—penetrate your sword arm at the first thrust, or lodge a bullet in your fore
head at forty yards.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p:
Keep cool—my hero keep cool! Oh! it's a clear case—it's a man, and here am I to rub off the rust, by being run through the bo
dy! sit down my fine fellow! sit down.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Fine fellow!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Ay, I see how it is—Sir Paul has adopted me out of joke, and you are to make mince meat of me for my vanity!

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Why, what is all this! (smiling.) mince meat!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: He smiles! then the joke's at an end, and they don't mean to hurt me! give me your hand—you comical dog, give me your hand.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Comical dog! what do you mean? explain.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Explain! nay: that's too bad—do you think I don't know you my jolly boy?—do you think I can't see you are a gentleman?

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: What! I a gentleman?

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Ay, and a brave one too!—why I suspected you at first sight!—I saw there was nothing feminine about you, and then when I looked you full in the face, "pooh," says I, this can never be a woman!

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Not a woman!—have I studied modern fashions? exceeded all the present race of high spirited women! only to be mistaken for—Oh Lord! I never wept before in all my life—but this—Oh, I shall faint—Oh! Oh!

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p:
My rascal of a son has gone off with all my papers—Darnley's note amongst the num
ber—and though Lady Sarah would give twice the value for it, I cannot find him—

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Hush! not so loud father—he'll flourish a sword—fire off a musket!

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: He!—who!—but how came you here, sir? in this disguise too!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Phoo!—it isn't me that's disguis'd; a word— (whispers to him)—there!

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: What! that lady!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: No; that comical dog—I'm sure of it—mum!

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p:
Ha! ha! ha!—you blockhead! why it's Lady Sarah Savage! she's rather masculine to be
sure: but Lord help you—she and I are old friends.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: What! you know her? do you!

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: Know her!—why I'll take my oath she's a woman.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: He'll take his oath!—Oh then I see my error—she's on the pavé, discarded; and they want to palm her on me.

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p:
Fool!—would you make more blun
ders! can't you tell a women of fashion from a—.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p:
No—there it is, sir,—if women of fashion will talk and dress like women of ano
ther description, who the devil can tell one from the other! and, if likewise they will hunt, shoot, and fence, and prefer masçuline assurance, to feminine diffidence, is it amazing, that a gentle
man should confound the sexes? however, I'm glad it's not a man.

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p:
Come—come—without further en
quiry, give me Darnley's note; the one Clara brought; the comical dog there, as you call her, is in love with Darnley, and wants to hold the bill as a rod over his head: I shall only ask her one hundred pounds premium for it.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.stage: (Taking the note out of his pocket book.)
sp.p: Only a hundred premium! heh!

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p:
No; I can afford it: and she, by arrest
ing him, can make her own terms—you under
stand!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Perfectly; so I'll shew her the note, and make peace— (goes towards Miss Savage, who is still sitting.)—madam—lady.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Pshaw! don't come near me, brute.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: I am convinc'd of my mistake, ma'am—this gentleman will take his oath on the subject, and therefore—in hopes of making amends—here is a note, my lady; a note of Mr. Darnley's for two hundred pounds.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: What did you say, sir?

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: A note of Mr. Darnley's, ma'am!

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p:
So it is; sign'd with his own dear hand— (rises)—well, now I look at you again, sir, I'm quite asham'd of our silly mis
understanding—I am indeed—he! he! perhaps it was my fault—nay—I dare say it was—and so, that's Mr. Darnley's note, is it?

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: It is, and now I recollect, wasn't the lady I conducted from the play, his wife?

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: It was—but entre nous—what's the price of that foolish bit of paper?

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p:
Only three hundred pounds! one hun
dred for the premium, and two for the princi
pal.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Here is the money then.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Softly; keep the principal, because you'll both want it, and as to the note, I'll keep that, lest somebody else should want it! (putting it in his pocket,) you brought me up to the trade, and if I haven't learnt a trick or two, Mr. Flush, it's no fault of yours.

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: What! would you turn swindler, you rascal!

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p:
Ay, this is a new mode of get
ting money.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p:
No—not so very new—is it Mr. Flush?—however, as the wife is the only person that ought to have a pow'r over the husband,
I'll e'en go instantly to Mrs. Darnley, and give it her.—

sp.speaker: Darnley,
sp.p: What, sir?

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: A note for two hundred pounds, sir,—have you any objections? never mind the loss of the premium, Mr. Flush—you can afford it, you know—adieu!—Mr. Bluff, (To Darnley, who is frowning,) your servant—it wouldn't do—you you comical dog, it wouldn't do!—

div.stage: (Shewing Lady Sarah Savage the note, and exit.)

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: 'Sdeath!—this is the very man you told me of.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Ay, now can you want further proof of his attachment to your wife?—I'll leave it to any body?—isn't it evident, Mr. Flush?

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: His giving her two hundred pounds is a strong circumstance to be sure—but then, when I recollect the money is mine, and not his—

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: What then, sir.

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: Why then, I think, the lady ought to be in love with me, and not him, sir.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: I'll set out for London, and never see her more—yet no—I'll be satisfied—I'll know the worst!—I'll instantly pursue this new found idol of her heart, and if I catch him in her presence—

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: Kill him—for a wretch, who can't distinguish the human species, isn't fit to live—come—I'll go with you.

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: So will I—but pray don't kill him, till I've got my papers.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p:
Nay, don't fret about it, Mr. Darnley—you shall return with me to Savage-house—come—never think of going to Lon
don at this time of year—it's so thin—all the great houses are lock'd up, and there's no mak
ing a fashionable party; is there, Mr. Flush?

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p:
Your pardon, ma'am—I and my attor
ney can always collect a fashionable party, and if the great houses are lock'd up, why there are great people in lock-up-houses, so don't be afraid of finding good company, Mr. Darnley!

div.head: SCENE II.—A library in Sir George Gauntlet's house.
div.stage: Sir GEORGE, and a servant meeting.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Sir! Sir! Mrs. Darnley is coming here to look for some books.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: That's fortunate: did you deliver my message to her, and her husband?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p:
I did, sir, I told them you were gone out of town, and would not return till to mor
row.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p:
Very well! then, in case of acci
dent, leave open the private door that leads behind the library. (Servant opens a door that leads be
hind the library.) A man of intrigue should al
ways have a place to lay snug in, and where is he so little likely to be discover'd, as amongst works of study and reflection! here she is!
mind we're not interrupted.
sp.stage: (Servant exit—Sir George retires towards the Library.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p:
Will Mr. Darnley never be con
vinc'd of this friend's hypocrisy! he is so credu
lous, that he even now places more confidence in him, than ever: I'm glad Sir George is out of town—I can at least pass another hour in peace, and—
sp.stage: (Going towards the Library, Sir George meets her.)

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p:
Don't be alarmed, Mrs. Darnley; I'm only a living volume, and if you will pe
ruse my thoughts, you'll read of nothing but your
self—you are engraved here in indelible letters, upon my honour.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Sir, I was inform'd—but this is no time for parleying—alone and unprotected!
sp.stage: (Going, Sir George stvnds in her way.)

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p:
Nay, you know I have long pro
fessed a regard for you; long thought you the finest woman on earth! and as a proof, didn't I offer you my hand, before my friend—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p:
Friend! call him by some other name, Sir George, and don't profane such ho
nourable terms.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Why, isn't he my friend? havn't I so completely gain'd his affections, that he wishes me to win yours? does he not bring you here—to my house!—leave me tête-a-tête with you! and in every respect prove so kind, so obliging—.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p:
Hold, sir—if he has exposed me to insults, I am the person to accuse him—not
you! I know his heart, and I know yours—one has my love—my esteem—the other—

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Has what, my sweet creature?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: My scorn.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Nay then—I must tell you, that when I condescend to love a woman, I always insist on making her happy; and therefore, with opportunity on my side, and the whole world to lay the blame on your husband—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: On him! the world is not so easily deceiv'd! but lest it should, I'll vindicate his fame—I'll proclaim the falsehood of his friend—his perfidy—

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Gently—gently—I see I must take advantage now or never!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: What do you mean, sir?

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: First to fasten the door, and then, my angel—
sp.stage:
(As he opens it to fasten it closely, Ging
ham enters and pushes by him.)

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: And then, my angel—to give you two hundred pounds—this note, ma'am, is Mr. Darnley's—it accidentally fell into my hands, and I designedly place it in yours—put it up, ma'am—keep it tight in your pocket; for what, with one having a rage for disguises—another having a rage for swindling—a third— (Seeing Sir George.)—ha! my judge of good breeding! is it you?

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: This blockhead has ruin'd one scheme already, I see.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p:
I'll tell you a secret Sir George; you fashionable people are very vulgar—it is your fine cloathes, gay equipages, and superb houses that are well bred, and not yourselves, egad! now only pull off that spangled coat—stick your
self behind a counter, and—.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Sir, don't you see I'm busy?

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: To be sure I do.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Why don't you leave the room then?

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Because I've no where else to go.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Then I command you; this lady and I are engag'd.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Engag'd, Sir George!—Sir, (to Gingham) if you'll conduct me to Mr. Darnley, I shall think myself a second time indebted to your gallantry.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Madam, I insist— (Crossing Mrs. D. and taking her by the hand,)—retire this instant, Sir—retire—

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Oh! I perceive—he detains her for base purposes! oh fie! fie!—fie for shame, Sir George—is this your good breeding!—your hand, ma'am—

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: 'Sdeath—obey me, or this sword, with which I've so often fought.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Often fought! what in earnest?

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Rascal! draw.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: No—I'd rather not.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: What! you don't like to fight!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: No—who the devil does! but you call me rascal, sir—now I've been long in doubt whether I am one or not—but if I was half as clear on the subject as you must be, I'd own it publickly—I'd say, "I Sir George Gauntlet am such a rude—ill bred—vulgar"—.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Coward!—come on—

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p:
Come on!—well! why shouldn't I! I may be alarm'd at masculine women, but I don't care that— (Snapping his fingers,)—for ef
feminate
men! so, though I never learnt to fence in all my life—though I don't know whether to hold my sword in my right hand or my left, have at thee!—ha!—ha!—

div.stage:
Sir GEORGE and GINGHAM make two or three pas
ses, when loud knocking at the door interrupts them.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p:
Zounds!—if this should be Darn
ley— (looks out.)—it is! I'm ruin'd—undone!—

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Ay, ay, I must take lessons—I'm touch'd—pink'd—
sp.stage: (shaking his hand which is slightly wounded.)

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p:
If I stir, I meet Darnley—hark'ye Sir— (aside to Gingham,)—that lady's husband is now on the stairs, and your present wound is on
ly a slight one; but if you hint or speak one word against my honour—

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: You'll run me through the body I suppose—well! as I can't fence—mum!

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: I shall not leave the room—I shall be conceal'd, and on the slightest insinuation, by heaven! I'll come forth and cut you into atoms; promise—or—you know my way—

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: I do—I'll live and fight another day.

div.stage: Sir GEORGE goes behind the Library unperceiv'd by GINGHAM or by Mrs. DARNLEY.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: I wish I knew the name of Sir George's fencing master— (Mrs. Darnley comes to him)—my dear ma'am, don't be uneasy—it's only graz'd, and if they don't send doctors and apothecaries to me, I shall live to pink him, again and again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Let me bind your hand, with my handkerchief. (Darnley enters behind.) Indeed—indeed, I owe you much.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: 'Tis now beyond a doubt—Oh woman! woman!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: You hav'nt got the rage—no, you are what a woman ought to be; mild, gentle, affectionate—an angel by all that's sacred.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: How! make love before my face! — (advances) So Mrs. Darnley —

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnly.
sp.p: Oh my dear!—I'm so glad you're come — this gallant, generous young man —

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: Generous young man!

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: Generous young man!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Has been wounded in my cause, and —

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: And you bound up his arm, with your handkerchief! —nay, don't deny it, madam—with my own eyes, I saw it—well, sir! what have you to say, sir? to that handkerchief, sir?

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p:
Say, sir!—why, I say, the handker
chief is as fine cambrick as ever was sold—twelve shillings a yard, sir!—at least I used to sell such for a guinea—a guinea, Mr. Bluff—as to any thing else, if you are the lady's hus
band —

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: I am her husband, sir!—who has long lov'd—long ador'd her!—and now comes here to witness her falsehood and his own dishonour.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p:
What does he say?—disho
nour!

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p:
Yes, madam—with him! with this gallant, generous young man! did he not last night accompany you from the play, and now do I not find you praising each other to my very
face?—observe me, Maria—as you have found me tender in my affections; so you shall find me severe in my resentment.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: I know not what he means: but I thought they'd make him hate me—I guilty of falsehood! dishonour to my husband! Oh, Harry! if you believe me so debas'd, take up that weapon, and pierce me to the heart!—in pity do!—I cannot live and know that you condemn me.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: Do you not love him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Whom!

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: Him.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Me!—love me!—I wish she did, for if I didn't use her better than you do, I'd cut my jealous head off!—look'ye, great lord and master!—she is more faithful to you, than you deserve—I know it, because just before you enter'd the room, Sir George Gauntlet, like a vile seducer as he is, was attempting to — (here a book falls from the library.) crau—au—au! (checking himself.) I shall be a dead man, before I know it.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p:
Sir George Gauntlet!—paltry eva
sions!—he is out of town and has so often prov'd himself a friend. —

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Friend!—Oh, Mr. Darnley! at last I am compell'd to tell you, he is your enemy and mine—it is that very friend, who would destroy your domestic peace; who would rob you of a heart, that is, and ever shall be all your own! and that, even now, might have triumph'd o'er a helpless woman, had not his friendly arm been stretch'd to serve me.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: It's true—I'll swear it!—I'll— (another book falls.) crau—au—au!

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p:
I'll not believe it—he is above such arts, and I would have you, madam, not en
crease your guilt, by daring to abuse my best of friends.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p:
Best of friends!—upon my soul▪ you've a rare set of acquaintance then.—Sir! I always had a knack at speaking what comes up
permost, and I say, Sir George wanted to turn me out, in order to lock her in—I say, he gave me this wound, in trying to defend her from his insolence—I say he is now conceal'd in this room!

div.stage: (Books fall from the Library, and leave an open space. GINGHAM looks round, and sees Sir GEORGE'S face frowning at him through the aperture.)

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: No—I don't say he is in the room—I don't! because—because— (looking round again) its better to be choak'd then kill'd.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p:
See how he prevaricates: and there
fore, that my friend may be slander'd and I deceiv'd no longer, 'tis time I should decide—Maria!—It almost kills me to pronounce it— (aside) we meet no more—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p: Stay—spare me but a moment—I cannot—will not lose him; Harry, think of our love—our children. —

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p:
Sir! sir!—let me ask you two ques
tions— (Another book falls, and Sir George frowns at him.) Ay, grin away you—Sir! can you sence, and will you fight?

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: Perhaps, you'll find, I can, sir.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: And if I prove that Sir George hid himself to avoid you, will you stand by, and see a poor fellow cut to atoms?

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: No—on the contrary, I shall be so convinc'd of the truth of your story —

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Say you so? then come out you black infernal seducer!

div.stage: (Runs up to the Library—forces open the front doors, and amidst the falling of all the books, Sir GEORGE GAUNTLET is discover'd!)

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: There—there he is! and now come on, if you dare—here's a pair of the best fencers in Europe?
sp.stage:
(Snatching up a sword and placing him
self by Darnley.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p:
'Tis all unravel'd—detested hypo
crite!

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Ah, Darnley!—how d'ye do!—this is a droll circumstance, isn't it!—but I hope you are convinc'd.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: Yes, sir, I am convinc'd.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: We're all convinc'd, sir.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p:
That you and Lady Sarah have join'd in a conspiracy to deceive me and betray my wife; that you have meanly put on the mask of friend
ship, to conceal the blackest artifices, and that if you had come to my house and boldly plun
der'd me of all my fortune—

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: He'd only have been hang'd!—but now he shall be cut to atoms.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Be cautious in your language, Mr. Darnley—you know my disposition.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p:
I do—I know you well: and hence
forth if you dare, either by action, word, or look; mark me, sir—raise but a blush in her unsullied
cheek, I will resent it—I'll inflict a punishment, great as your arrogance deserves!

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Arrogance!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Ay, arrogance!—are you deaf!

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Sir, this requires an explanation; you shall hear from me.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Pooh!

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p:
Delay not then, for I shall leave your house this moment, (Sir George exit.)—come Ma
ria—to you and this gentleman I have a thousand apologies—

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Bless you! I'm amply paid in letting my tongue wag—and as to any thing else, allow me once more to speak my mind to your sweet cousin, Clara! come let's go to her—Oh! you well bred ruffian!—to be first pink'd, and then nearly choak'd by such a —; on the whole, though, I never fought better in all my life!

div.head: SCENE I.—A Room in a Tavern—Dinner under Covers—Darnley discover'd sitting at the Table— Waiter attending.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p:
Tell Sir George Gauntlet, Mr. Darn
ley is waiting—what's o'clock?

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: Six, sir.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: The time draws near—I wonder where my friend can be? put some wine on the table and leave me.

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p:
Sir George is below, in close conver
sation with a gentleman, who seems anxious to see you, sir.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p:
His second, I suppose—tell him, I am here— (Waiter exit.) 'Sdeath!—to what have I reduc'd myself?—I that had every joy this world can give—a peaceful home—a wife that lov'd, and children that rever'd me!—I to be now in a tavern, on the eve of meeting with a pro
fess'd duellist? to be about to commit murder, or else to live dishonour'd and disgrac'd—Oh, Maria!—when thou shalt hear thy husband is no more, wilt thou forgive me?—wilt thou— but my fate determines hers, and if I fall she is for ever lost!

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p:
The gentleman from Sir George Gaunt
let, sir.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: Admit him—now then for the event!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: I'm so fag'd—so completely knock'd up (sees the dinner.) ha, ha! what's here?—the very thing to revive me.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p:
I hope, sir, you haven't been talk
ing to Sir George.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p:
Yes, but I have though—you em
ploy'd me as second, and if you're shot, it shall be in the way I like best. (sitting down) Waiter! waiter!

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.stage: (To Gingham, who is going to pull off a cover of one of the dishes.)
sp.p: Sir! sir!—Sir George order'd that dish not to be touch'd till he came.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p:
Did he?—then it's the pick'd thing I suppose, so I'll eat it all up directly, (uncovers it, and sees a brace of pistols laying 'midst powder and ball.) here—it's quite at his service, and I wish the whole were in his stomach with all my soul!— (giving the dish to the waiter, and uncover
ing another.) Ah! here's something that I can swallow. (begins eating.) Well after hunting every where for Sir George, I found him below stairs at last—"so" says I "my little Librarian"—al
luding to the book-case you know—"when are you and this jealous husband"—alluding to you, you know—"to fight this foolish duel?" (drinks a glass of wine.) Clara! my dear Clara Sedley!

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: Well, sir.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p:
Says I "the fact is this; one will be kill'd, the other be hang'd, and the world get rid of two hot-headed fellows:" says he, "Will
Darnley make me an apology?" says I "he might as well."

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: You did not!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p:
Ah, but I did though "it's very well for fashionable husbands, to leave their wives with friends, in hopes of getting divorces and damages; but what right," says I, "has a country squire to quit his farm, and trust his wife, with baronets, fools, and coxcombs?— to plant his own horns" says I! (drinks.) "Suc
cess to trade."

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: And how did this end, sir?

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p:
How!—why the other second in
terfer'd—said Sir George could'nt fire at you, and advised him to apologize—he hesitated— I put my hand on my sword—reminded him of my fine fencing—he sign'd this paper—I've al
ready shewn it to Mrs. Darnley, and so— (drinks) Here's the child that has two fathers!

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: 'Tis ample, final satisfaction—wasn't my Maria happy?

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p:
She was—but with women, grief soon follows joy, you know—she says, your un
cle, whoever he is, has order'd you to quit Bath, and go abroad—that she is to be left behind, and as your fortune is exhausted, she fears you must consent—I'm sorry I'm pinch'd too—however— (drinks.) Here's confusion to your stingy old uncle!

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: Unfeeling! persecuting man!—separate me from all I love—I know the motive for this barbarous conduct—he has found a son, on whom he means to lavish all his favours, and while he rolls in luxury, I and my family may starve —may—but he comes.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p:
So Mr. Darnley: how dare you in
trude into the houses of great people, and thus repeatedly disgrace me?—look'ye, sir—I have made up my mind—you must seek your fortune abroad—I'll pay your expences to the continent, and lest your family should be a burthen to you, I'll provide for your wife at home.

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: Oh, sir! do not part us!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p:
I will!—I'm resolv'd! (seeing Ging
ham.) hah!—what do I see?—my boy!—my darling!—how came you here you rogue?

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Father, you're come in time—just in time to finish the bottle! (filling him a humper, and putting it in his hand) drink! drink the last toast!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Ay, what is it?

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: "Confusion to Darnley's"—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: With all my heart—"confusion to Darnley's"—

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: "Stingy old uncle!"

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Stingy old uncle!—why that's confusion to myself you dog!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p:
What! is it you—well! hang me if I didn't think it was my father—that is my other father, the money-lender—cousin—rela
tion—how are you!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Nonsense! never mind him—I've brought you your commission—a company in a regiment serving in Ireland.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Have you! (to Sir Paul.) who'd have thought my father was your miserly uncle, heh!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: It's three hundred a-year, my boy! psha! don't mind him I tell you, (pulling him away from Darnley.) I reserve every thing for you—I always meant to give all I could to my son.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Did you!—Oh then it comes to the same point; why, perhaps, you'll give me two hundred pounds.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Ay, that I will.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: What! and the commission too!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p:
Yes, and the commission too! here they are both—and some ten years hence, I'll join the regiment, and serve under you; un
der my brave son!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p:
No—under your brave nephew if you like—I don't understand the exercise, and Darnley does! and therefore, as we're all rela
tions—all in a family, I'll e'en give him the commission—Nay, don't be shy cousin—it makes no difference father, does it?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Death and fire! it does, sir, it makes all the difference, and I swear—

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Softly—you can make me a hero in another way—as I was brought up to trade, pop me into the train bands—then I can be kill'd in the artillery ground in one day, and be alive in the shop the next! so keep the commission, cousin; keep it— (Forcing it into Darnley's hand.) and here—here's the money to take you, your wife and children to Ireland— (giving the bank notes.—there! now moderate your joy, father! you've done a kind, generous action to be sure: but why! why in such an ecstacy!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Ecstacy! agony you puppy!

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p:
Gently, gently, at the public break
fast I shall sound forth your praises—come,
cousin—the best of the joke is, I've another fa
ther; and though he wont lend you a shilling, I'll make him send you linen enough to shirt your whole regiment.—Farewell, thou liberal man!— look!—Self-gratification has brought tears of joy into his eyes!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p:
Tears of joy!—if being cheated out of my money, makes me cry for pleasure, what shall I do, if I get it back again?—was there ever such a fellow?—however the com
mission is of no use to Darnley—but then the two hundred pounds—and the ease with which he did it.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: A letter from your Ward, Sir Paul. It requires an immediate answer.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.q:
Sir, I am now at the Public Breakfast, where Miss Savage ac
tually insisted on my coming. I have discover
ed a deep plot of Mr. Savage's, and when I tell you, I am in danger of being run away with, without my consent, I'm sure you will fly to the relief of your—Affectionate Ward, CLARA SEDLEY.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p:
I'll come directly— (Servant exit.)— So—So—they have heard of her sudden acqui
sition of fortune—of the Copper Mines being discovered on her estate, and now like true sava
ges, they mean to paw the property—but I've a husband for her in my eye. She has formed an affection for this liberal son of mine, and the dog can't take her for a man in woman's cloathes.

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: You knave!—if I catch you—how! has he left the tavern!—Ah! Sir Paul!—pray Sir, have you seen any thing of my son?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: I know nothing of your son, sir.

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: He has been distributing my property— giving away my money, Sir Paul.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: 'Gad! My son has been doing me the same favour.

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: Ay, sir; but my son has swindled me out of two hundred pounds.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: That's the exact sum!—my son has swindled me out of—so let's shake hands and cry for joy!

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p:
Well, well—I can afford it—but, Sir Paul, there is only one way he can make me retribution—you've heard of our ward's copper mines, and though you have only known me as a private gentleman, and I you as joint guar
dian—yet I think you will consent to her marrying the man I propose.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: And pray, who may the gentleman be?—not the Honourable Mr. Savage, I hope, for he has no property, but my two racers.

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: No—no—my Son!—my rogue of a Son!—will you agree?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Why I would with pleasure only—

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: What Brother Guardian?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: I mean to propose my rogue of a son.

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: Your son!—why how came you by a son?—but to the point—my boy has won her heart, Sir Paul.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: So has mine too, Mr. Flush.

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: Yours too!—Sdeath, Sir Paul—this racing has turned your brain.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Racing!—Iv'e done with it, sir— I hate it—I'm above the turf now.

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: Above the turf!—I wish you were under it!—do you pretend she loves both our sons?—two men at the same time, sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p:
To be sure—she's not the first wo
man that has lov'd twenty at the same time, sir— but as she can't marry without our joint consent, and is now in great distress at Lady Sarah Sa
vage's public breakfast, let's adjourn there di
rectly.

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: With all my heart—I can afford it— Publick breakfast!—why this is later than usual— (Looking at his Watch)—Nine o'clock at night!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Ah, these are late hours: but what need we care, Mr. Flush?—we that have health, youth, spirits—do you know there is only one house in England that affects my constitution?

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: And what house is that?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: I never was there but twice—the first time there was a motion about relieving poor insolvent debtors, and the house was so empty I got an ague. The next time, somebody mov'd to remove the hackney coaches from Bond-Street, and the benches were so cram'd that I was thrown into a sever!—So hey for the breakfast.—Youth's the season made for joy!

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: Love is then our duty! &c.

div.head:
SCENE II.—A garden at Mr. Savage's on Lans
aown hill—a marquee at the upper wing, in which is seen a table full of fruits, wine, meat, tea urns, coffee pots, &c. A distant view of Bath—moon rising.—Long flourish of clarinets!
div.stage: Enter Lady SARAH SAVAGE and a Servant.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p:
Call Miss Clara— (Servant enters marquee.)—I have given this party in order to secure this young creature and her fortune, for my brutish brother has so lessen'd our gold, that only her copper can save us from sinking—if her guardians refuse, we are prepar'd for bolder schemes.
Enter CLARA. Well: my dear girl, how do you like our break
fast? —breakfast by moonlight? isn't it quite charming—so nouvêlle?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Quite—and in addition to tea and coffee, here are fowls, fruit, and wine, so that you may breakfast, dine, drink tea, and sup all in the same meal—nouvêlle!—surely nobody else is so singular.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: I don't know—I never copy—the world's so very ignorant—that only act unlike other people, and you're pretty sure of being right, but, didn't you like the music—the singing?—

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p:
No; I don't much like these sine sing
ers —it's a long time before you prevail on them to sing, and then when they once begin—faith! they never stop. I declare I only saw one person I liked amongst the party.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: And who was that?—the dear Signor!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: No—the dear creature, my guardian's son.

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p: What! that monster? I wonder who invited such a heterogeneous animal, and you to prefer him—

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Even to your brother, Ma'am—I know Mr. Savage designs me his hand; but, if my guardians will agree—and why they leave me in this scene of danger when I wrote to Sir Paul—

sp.speaker: Lady Sarah.
sp.p:
Here they are both—I'll go call my brother, and by the time I return, I hope I shall call you sister—adieu!—Gingham, in
deed!

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: Here she is—here's the girl to answer for herself—now be cool, Sir Paul—compose yourself, and I'll fairly put the question to her. Clara, haven't you fix'd your affections?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: To confess the truth, I have, Sir.

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: Very well—softly, Sir Paul! and now, what is the Gentleman's name?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Ay, what is his name, Clary?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Gingham, Sir.

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: There! I told you so—it's my son!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Why there! I told you so—it's my son!

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: Your son!—In the first place I don't believe you have a son; and in the next, do you pretend that this Gingham—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Is my boy! my own darling child!— and I'll prove it.

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: Well, well, if this is the case. I'll make you a fair proposition, let's call in both our sons, and let the one she prefers be her husband.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p:
Agreed—and I'll bet you a hun
dred pounds she chuses mine.

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: Done,—I'll bet you a hundred she chuses mine.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: My life! my love! my Clara!

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: Here he comes!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Here he comes

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: I cannot live a moment from thee—I—

div.stage: GINGHAM enters from the Marquee, and, seeing his two fathers together, pauses and starts.

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: Now, Clara—Silence, Sir Paul!—don't you chuse him!—him!—for your husband?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: I do, Sir.

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: Huzza! I've won my bet!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Here is a father don't know his own child.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p:
And here's a child don't know his own father! upon my soul, Gentlemen, I cannot tell which of you had the honour of inventing me; but here I am, and if you have more property to distribute—if either of you has another two hundred pounds, I'll dis
pose of it so nearly, that tears of joy shall trickle down your cheeks!

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.stage: (After looking some time at Sir Paul.)
sp.p: Sir Paul!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p:
Mr. Flush—We were joint guar
dians just now and—

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: And now we're joint fathers it seems.—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: This must be the tradesman—a word in private, if you please, Sir. (They enter the Marquee.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Lay your heads together; settle it as you please; for while Clara smiles on me, I care not whether I'm son to a haberdasher, or heir to the grand Turk.

sp.speaker: Cara.
sp.p: I hope they won't quarrel—I fear Mr. Flush will insist—

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: He insist!—bless you, he'd sell me for half a crown.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p:
He's mine! he's mine! the father knows his own child at last.—I never suspected Flush was clerk to a Lottery Office, and conse
quently little thought he was the tradesman who married my Nelly—'gad! I always took him for a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Did you?—that was very good natur'd of you—and so you give me up, Mr. Flush?

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p:
Yes, I can afford it.—The Tunbridge story is perfectly explain'd, and I have done with you, you rogue—Your wise father here has pro
mis'd to restore my papers, so now you may speak truth till you're black in the face.

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p:
May I? —then I won't; lest other faces should be of the same complexion—but, gentlemen, since you've found out who I belong to, will you inform me who this lady is to be
long to?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Ay, Mr. Flush—I'm sure I shall have your consent—you are a monied man and have lived with people of rank.

sp.speaker: Flush.
sp.p: Your pardon, ma'am, if I had lived with people of rank, I had not been a monied man—the fact is, I touch cash wherever I can, and Sir Paul has brib'd me so handsomely, that I have sold my consent—I have sold my ward as well as my son, and for this plain reason—I can afford it.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p:
Clary, take his hand, my Girl. (Giv
ing her to Gingham.) The dog has an odd way of speaking his mind, but instead of checking him, encourage him; many a man only wants to be told of his errors to correct them, and that is my case—

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Your case, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Yes, my boy—since you talked of self-gratification bringing tears of pleasure into my eyes, I resolv'd to try the experiment—I determin'd to retrench my expences, to sell my hounds, dispose of my stud, and see if I could not lay out my money on rational and solid pleasures; in bestowing happiness on two as innocent and injur'd creatures as ever existed!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p:
Niece, your hand—Darnley for
give what's past, and henceforth if I don't prove a friend to you, tell that son of mine to speak his mind to me—tell him to take another two hundred pounds out of my pocket; nay, dis
perse my whole property—any thing, so you don't drink "Confusion to a stingy old uncle!"

sp.speaker: Mrs. Darnley.
sp.p:
Sir, we owe every thing to your son—he has been our pilot through the storms of fashion, and if he now secures to us in
dependence and our cottage—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Independence and a cottage! S'life! you shall have affluence and a farm as large as Salisbury Plain—I'll come and see you every summer! ay! for sixty years to come!—odsheart! they say I'm like an old Volcano burnt out! but it's a mistake—I'm like an Egyptian lamp that flames for ever!—A'nt I, my boy?

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Must I speak truth, father?—mum!

sp.speaker: Darnley.
sp.p: You have made me the happiest of men, Sir Paul; but you must excuse me when I say, that your son has the first and greatest claim—

sp.speaker: Gingham.
sp.p: Nay, Cousin; if you knew me half as well as I know myself, you would find I have as many faults as any of you.—But come, let's adjourn from this vulgar fashionable scene, and while they drink one toast, we'll give another—

q.l: The charms that constitute each female grace.
To man, be bold and daring schemes confin'd,
Woman for softer passions was design'd,
And by meek virtue—to subdue mankind!
